rank_62.title: London Games would 'inspire athletes of tomorrow'
rank_62.text:
Holding the 2012 Olympic Games in London would offer a "vision of inspiration" for future generations, the city's bid team told the International Olympic Committee in Singapore today.

The London 2012 team made their final presentation to the IOC, which included a recorded message from the prime minister, Tony Blair, in both French and English - the two official languages of the committee.

"Our vision is to see millions more young people - in Britain and across the world - participating in sport and improving their lives as a result of that participation," Mr Blair said. "London has the power to make that happen. It is a city with a voice that talks to young people."

The prime minister's appeal was echoed by the London 2012 committee chairman and double Olympic winner Sebastian Coe.

Lord Coe drew upon memories of how the Mexico Olympics had inspired him to become a world-class athlete, telling the IOC that giving the games to London would "inspire the athletes of tomorrow".

"It is a critical decision about which bid offers the vision and sporting legacy but protects the Olympic Games," he said. "It is a decision about which city shows a generation why sport matters.

"That's what drives me to do whatever we can to inspire young people to choose sport - whatever they do, whatever they believe and wherever they live. Choose London today, and you send a clear message to the youth of the world - the Olympic Games is for you."

Princess Anne opened London's presentation and read out a message from the Queen. In it, the monarch said she hoped all 115 IOC members would be in London in 2012 and would visit Buckingham Palace.

Almost half London's delegation of guests in Singapore are athletes and children - a reminder to the IOC that trying to inspire future generations and regenerating London's East End were central to London's bid.

The capital's bid team flew 30 schoolchildren, aged between 12 and 18, to Singapore. "Why are so many here taking the place of politicians and businessmen? It's because we are serious about inspiring young people," Lord Coe said.

Each of the five cities were given 45 minutes in which to make a final presentation to the IOC before the vote, the result of which is due at 7.46pm local time (1246 BST).

Paris made the first presentation, and was followed by New York, Moscow, London and Madrid.

The French capital's presentation included a film by the Hollywood director Luc Besson and a keynote speech by the French president, Jacques Chirac.

Mr Chirac made much of the fact this was the third time in 20 years that Paris, which hosted the Games in 1924, has bid.

rank_210.title: London 2012: Legacy is key to 2012
rank_210.text:
Sebastian Coe, the chairman of London 2012, insisted yesterday that increased participation in sport and improved public facilities were at the heart of the Olympic project after criticism that creating a sporting legacy was being neglected.

The issue - which was instrumental in London winning its bid to stage the games - dominated the annual conference of the Central Council of Physical Recreation (CCPR) after its chief executive Tim Lamb called for a single body to be given responsibility for delivering a legacy of physical activity throughout the UK.

Lamb said no single organisation could be held to account on the legacy issue. "Thought needs to be given now to how we can get people up out of their armchairs and into the courts, pitches and pools which the Olympics will leave and which already exist across the country. We need a plan for a legacy of participation and we need it before the sites are built, not as an afterthought."

The CCPR, which has 270 member organisations from football to folk dancing and bowling to bridge, and represents 150,000 clubs across Britain, said the success of 2012 would be judged on more than just medals.

Lamb said the CCPR should have a seat at the top table determining legacy issues, but Coe said the process was best overseen by the four members of the Olympic Board: Tessa Jowell, the Olympics minister, Ken Livingstone, mayor of London, Lord Moynihan, chairman of the British Olympic Association and Coe, himself, as chairman of the organising committee.

Coe told the conference that legacy was "absolutely epicentral" to the plans for 2012. "Legacy is probably nine-tenths of what this process is about, not just 16 days of Olympic sport," he said.

Roger Draper, chief executive of the Lawn Tennis Association, said more investment was needed in club structure and coaching in the middle ground between school and elite sport. "I would hate it for kids to walk out in 2012 to rotting facilities, no coaches and poor infrastructure."

rank_248.title: 2012: No cut-price Olympic legacy for football's fat cats
rank_248.text:
West Ham United and Tottenham Hotspur are "extremely unlikely" to move into London's main Olympic stadium after the event in 2012, according to senior figures organising the Games. The Olympic Delivery Authority has held discussions with both clubs but is maintaining its original plan to build the Olympic and Paralympic Games' central venue with 80,000 mostly temporary seats and then scale it down to a 25,000-capacity stadium still containing an athletics track.

The ODA and Ken Livingstone, the mayor of London, are responsible for securing a sustainable "legacy" for the massive public money - upwards of £2bn - which will be spent on hosting the Olympics, and there is no appetite for millions of it to subsidise a Premier League football club which wants a bigger home on the cheap. The London organisers are determined not to repeat what was done in Manchester where £120m of public money was spent building a permanent stadium for the 2002 Commonwealth Games - and then the track was removed so the stadium could be handed to Manchester City on terms regarded as startlingly generous.

That deal - under which City pay no rent up to an attendance of 32,500 then share revenue above that gate with the local council - is thought to have encouraged the London clubs to hope a similar gift horse was riding into Greenwich. However the ODA has made it clear that if the stadium is to host football after the Games with, say, a 60,000 permanent capacity - at an extra cost which some informed sources put at about £200m - this will not come out of public money. The clubs would have to pay for it themselves and that has sent them away disappointed.

"The option is still outstanding," David Higgins, the ODA chief executive said, "but we are moving ahead to procure the stadium with a 25,000-seat legacy."

West Ham, the subject of takeover speculation and carrying £40m of debts, are not considered a realistic prospect to take on the stadium, and Tottenham are a long way from having the required amount of money - although both want to expand their grounds.

The London Development Agency, which is contributing £260m to the Olympics and is responsible for securing a broader economic and social legacy, is understood to be wary of a football club moving into the new stadium as it would require a current ground to be demolished. Manchester City's Maine Road ground in the deprived area of Moss Side has been knocked down; housing is planned for the site.

The determination not to spend extra money creating an unnecessarily lavish stadium which ultimately boosts the life-chances of a privately owned Premier League club is part of the wider commitment to secure a sustainable legacy.

Of the new venues due to be built, only the 10,000-seat handball arena will remain as a permanent facility after the Games. The aquatic centre, the first to go out to tender, will remain for the local community in the Lea Valley but its seating will be reduced from 20,000 to a more realistic capacity of 3,500; the velodrome, hockey stadium and paralympic tennis centre will either be reduced in size or reconfigured after the Games; three venues are to be dismantled and relocated elsewhere in the country, while two more, the 8,000-capacity fencing arena and 5,000-seat water polo pool, will be temporary structures.

"We are building facilities to match future use and a viable business case," Higgins said. "Some major events leave a fabulous stadium but with huge ongoing operating costs. We've said all along: no white elephants."

The cost, however, is still enormous. The total funding for the Olympics made available from the national lottery, London council tax payers and the LDA is £2.375bn - but the final building costs are likely to require substantial additional taxpayers' money, following discussions Higgins has held recently with the Treasury. In addition, the London Organising Committee for the Olympic Games (Locog) needs to raise £2bn from the private sector to pay for the running of the Games.

Construction of the venues has not yet gone out to tender so there are no detailed designs but I understand that a working estimate for building the main Olympic stadium, even with temporary seating and reduction post-Games to 25,000 seats, is put at about £350m. The ODA will look to appoint a contractor to design and build a stadium of the quality needed for such a prestigious event, and also an adviser to plan the 25,000-seat version's long-term viability afterwards - which should include use by the community and possibly a new school, as well as sporting events.

With 40,000 homes due to be built and 60,000 jobs promised, including for the sizeable deprived population in the Lea Valley, the Olympics forms part of wider east London regeneration plans for which Mayor Livingstone is responsible. There have been worries within his office recently that in the drive towards hosting a successful Olympics in 2012, these more solid social benefits could be lost.

"There was some concern," according to Neale Coleman, the mayor's Olympics adviser, "that the regeneration, social and economic legacies could fall between the ODA and Locog, and dribble away. We have made a concerted effort to ensure that does not happen. We have produced a series of documents so that all the authorities, including the government, are signed up in concrete terms to what needs to be done. The same is happening nationally and the process is almost complete."

One example on which the LDA is particularly keen is for local people to be given training, skills and employment on constructing the venues, and for this to be included as a formal commitment by whichever contractors are taken on.

There is one central part of the Olympic promise which still risks being neglected: the pledge by the prime minister, Tony Blair, that the Olympics will inspire a new generation of young people to play more sport. The risk is the opposite - that money will be diverted from investment in community facilities as £750m of lottery money is earmarked for the Olympics, including about £290m from Sport England so far, with another hefty amount due to be pledged.

Official plans are being produced to develop sport nationally - backed by major public money - but Sport England is concerned whether the government will provide enough cash to match its rhetoric, and truly boost participation.

Who pays for 2012?

Total estimated cost of Games £4.375bn

£2bn from private sector

£750m From National Lottery (new games)

£750m National Lottery (general funds)

£625m London council-tax payers

£250m London Development Agency

rank_84.title: Jonathan Glancey: Ill-defined plans could leave a disastrous legacy for 2012 Olympics
rank_84.text:
No one really knows how much the London Olympics will cost - not Sir Roy McNulty, head of the grimly named Olympic Delivery Authority, nor Tessa Jowell, secretary of state for culture, media and sport, nor even the mayor of London. Common sense tells us to assume several billion more than the current figure. Onwards and domewards.

To a national chorus of low-level grumbling, this lumbering, bullying, ill-tempered and overpoliticised roadshow will gasp towards completion, with a final hugely expensive sprint, run by relays of cheap imported labour. The games themselves will be short-lived, of course, but an event many, if not all, of us will whoop at in front of giant TV screens in smokeless pubs or, with take-aways on our laps, in the privacy of homes taxed to the rafters for the big event.

Sir Roy says the original Olympics budget was put together without a full analysis of the site or fully costed designs for new venues. For today's top business folk operating in the cloud-cuckoo world of PPP and PFI finances, this sort of oversight is purely a matter of course. Give the man a bonus. But there is a fundamental, and costly, problem with the way Britain has been bludgeoning its way towards 2012. This is the conflation of the Olympics and urban "regeneration". While the first may be costed with some degree of accuracy, the price of the latter may as well be infinite.

While the games themselves will occupy a specific site, the associated "regeneration" area has no ultimate boundaries and thus no final cost. "Regeneration" is a word, and creed, bandied about by politicians inspired, like prophets, by what they like to call "vision". The vision they share with fast-breeding quangos and saintly property developers is one of "vibrant" and "sustainable" communities stretching out towards the chalcedony-lined streets of some future New Jerusalem. But where and how far will this brave and costly Olympian world of Shanghai-style offices blocks and US-style shopping malls reach? Dagenham? Up the M11 to Cambridge? No one knows.

What we do know is that the stretch of the river Lea winding through the Olympic Park has been at the heart of the 2012 regeneration "vision". According to the mayor of London's Lower Lea Valley Opportunity Area Planning Framework document, "the overall vision is to transform the lower Lea valley to become a vibrant, high-quality and sustainable mixed-use city district that is fully integrated into the urban fabric of London and is set within an unrivalled landscape that contains new high-quality parkland and water features".

This is regeneration yak on an Olympian scale. This particular report does not spell out, beyond "water features" and acres of office space, shops for rent and "affordable" homes, what specific industries and jobs might be coming this way from 2012. And yet, to capitalise on a presumed Olympic legacy, and to keep costs finite and justifiable, all those working on the Olympic "vision" need to tell us just what is planned for these promised lands.

It would be far better to invest in one shining regeneration project, even if modest, than to attempt to cure all London's ills by chucking money about like some wildly generous drunk. Imagine, for example, if the Olympic team were able to build just one happily confined new London district. Handsome, compact, flood-proof homes, sheltered from the bitter winds scything through the Lea valley, connected to arcades of shops and useful services, served by public transport and within walking distance of schools and worthwhile jobs.

The Olympic Park stands on the old Great Eastern Railway locomotive works; the banks of the Lea were once lined with what was, in its day, hi-tech industry. The spirit of this place should encourage the construction not of millions of square feet of offices and chain stores - nor simplistic talk of "parkland and water features", nor even of how many millions of pounds the games might generate for the economy - but of well-serviced accommodation for future industry.

Imagine London designing and building its own low-energy bus fleet here. Imagine the latest biotech and nano-tech laboratories on the banks of the Lea. Imagine real jobs for local people. Such innovation might well encourage the best and most exciting new European industry, and be worth at least some of the political aggression driving the nastiest Olympics yet held.

· Jonathan Glancey is the Guardian's architecture critic



jonathan.glancey@theguardian.com

rank_230.title: Debate: Will the legacy of 2012 be worth all the extra cost?
rank_230.text:
Yes: David Higgins - Olympic Delivery Authority chief executive

One thing we haven't been short of since London was awarded the 2012 Games is talk about costs - a raft of different and speculative figures have been mentioned in the last few weeks alone. What has been missing from the cost debate is any real focus on value and what we call the other side of the balance sheet - the regeneration opportunity that hosting the Games provides. London 2012 can be remembered as the Games for the next generation.

One of the questions currently being addressed is how best to harness the power of the Olympic and Paralympic Games to change one of the poorest parts of the country for good. A quick look at the Olympic Park size makes it clear why leaving a lasting legacy is at the heart of the vision for 2012. The Lower Lea Valley is scarred by derelict land. Decades of under-investment have left the area a virtual industrial wasteland, home to some of the most deprived communities in the country.

Our regeneration ambition is to build a new town the size of Exeter in the Lower Lea Valley, all on recycled brown-field land that in legacy will provide thousands of new homes; new transport links and infrastructure; alongside world-class sports facilities in one of the largest new urban parks in Europe for 150 years. This transformation will be matched by opportunities for significant social and economic change.

And while this investment is about far more than just a month of sport, let us not also underestimate the priceless value that hosting the world's biggest sporting event will bring. This is a once in-a-lifetime opportunity value that hosting the world's biggest sporting event will bring. The transformative power of the Olympic Games will help inspire a new generation of young people to participate in sport up and down the country.

Plans to develop the Lower Lea Valley have been around for many years - the pot marked regeneration is money that would always eventually have had to be spent on this neglected part of East London. But none of this would be possible in such a short time frame were it not for London winning the Games. The Games are the catalyst for accelerating change and we are locking in legacy right at the start of the planning process.

The Games can be viewed not so much as a cost but as an investment. Let us not forget why so many cities compete for the privilege for the Games - they recognise the benefits and the opportunities they will bring. This is a once-in-a-lifetime opportunity and we will have failed if we look back post 2012 and regret that we didn't have the vision to make the most of the prize.

It is right when we are talking about taxpayers' money that there is real scrutiny about costs. The debate will continue for a while longer yet. But one thing I am certain of - the legacy will last infinitely longer and will continue to shine long after the Olympic and Paralympic flames leave London in 2012.

No: Tim Lamb - Central Council for Physical Recreation chief executive

In all the hot air which has risen from the debate about London's Olympics and Paralympics in recent weeks, there is one word which has been conspicuously absent - sport. But this should not come as a surprise. Ministers know that nothing heats the air of an Olympic story more than a rising budget - and some reports now estimate that the budget has doubled since the bid.

Hosting a Games was always going to be a hugely expensive undertaking. But can taxpayers be assured that the Games and the legacy they leave will represent good value for money?

Governing bodies of sport and recreation would argue that while they want these Olympics they should not come at any price. Make no mistake, there can be no group more excited about the possibilities the Games bring. The defining feature of the London bid, that "grassroots participation would be boosted and an already sports-mad nation would get fitter and healthier" told them all they wanted to hear. The government was committed to creating a legacy of participation from the Games which would last a lifetime.

Today, however, that legacy recedes with each budget increase. For every extra pound spent on security or project management a pound must be found from somewhere else. Depending on where those extra pounds are raised, a rising budget could be catastrophic for the participation legacy, pushing the Games past the price of acceptability. Ministers would be well advised to do two things to keep that price within bounds which would retain the support of sport and the wider public. The first is to rule out raiding the lottery. Olympic lottery games are already drawing funds away from other distributors as part of the original funding plan. Sport England is also contributing £290m, the equivalent of hundreds of new community clubhouses and all-weather pitches. But as the budget balloons, top-slicing the funds raised by the generic lottery games becomes more attractive to ministers.

The effect of this would be to decimate funding for grassroots sport (and countless other good causes) through the lottery. This would not only damage the ability of community clubs to step up and meet the Olympic legacy challenge, it could threaten sports' ability just to stand still.

The second is for ministers to take a step back and think about what they set out to achieve. As 2012 approaches, there will be a tendency to concentrate on the smooth-running of the event itself. But ministers must also try to remember the wider objectives they had in mind when they decided toback a bid; not least promoting sport and activity. If the Games' potential is to be truly fulfilled, then ministers must look again at what the price, and cost in terms of opportunity, of an unfettered Olympic bill could be.

rank_260.title: George Monbiot: London is getting into the Olympic spirit - by kicking out the Gypsies
rank_260.text:
Everything we have been told about the Olympic legacy turns out to be bunkum. The games are supposed to encourage us to play sport; they are meant to produce resounding economic benefits and help the poor. It's all untrue. As the evictions in London begin, a new report shows that the only certain Olympic legacy is a transfer of wealth from the poor to the rich.

Both Lord Coe and Tessa Jowell, the sports secretary, like the boosters for every city to have bid for the Olympics, have claimed that the games will lever us off our sofas and turn us into a nation of athletes. But Jowell knows this is nonsense. In 2002 her department published a report which found that "hosting events is not an effective, value-for-money method of achieving ... a sustained increase in mass participation". One study suggests that the Olympics might even reduce our physical activity: we stay indoors watching them on TV, rather than kicking a ball around outside. And this is before we consider the effects of draining the national lottery: Sport England will lose £100m.

The government's favourite thinktanks, Demos and the Institute for Public Policy Research, examined the claim that the Olympics produce a lasting economic boom. They found that "there is no guaranteed beneficial legacy from hosting an Olympic games ... and there is little evidence that past games have delivered benefits to those people and places most in need". Tessa Jowell must be aware of this as well - she wrote the forward to the report. A paper published by the London assembly last month found that "long-term unemployed and workless communities were largely unaffected [by better job prospects] by the staging of the games in each of the four previous host cities".

Far more damning is a study released last week by the Centre on Housing Rights and Evictions. In every city it examined, the Olympic games - accidentally or deliberately - have become a catalyst for mass evictions and impoverishment. Since the 1988 Olympics in Seoul, more than 2 million people have been driven from their homes to make way for the Olympics. The games have become a licence for land grabs.

The 1988 games are widely seen as a great success. But they were used by the military dictatorship (which had ceded power in 1987) as an opportunity to turn Seoul from a vernacular city owned by many people into a corporate city owned by the elite - 720,000 people were thrown out of their homes; people who tried to resist were beaten by thugs and imprisoned; tenants were evicted without notice and left to freeze (some survived by digging caves into a motorway embankment); street vendors were banned; homeless people, those with mental health problems, alcoholics and beggars were rounded up and put into a prison camp. The world saw nothing of this: just a glossy new city full of glossy new people.

Barcelona's Olympics, in 1992, are cited as a model to which all succeeding Olympic cities should aspire. But, though much less destructive than Seoul's, they were also used to cleanse the city. Roma communities were evicted and dispersed. The council produced a plan to "clean the streets of beggars, prostitutes, street sellers and swindlers" and "annoying passers-by". Some 400 poor and homeless people were subjected to "control and supervision". Between 1986 and 1992 house prices rose by 240% as the Olympic districts were gentrified, while the public housing stock fell by 76%. There was no consultation before the building began - the games were too urgent and important. Around 59,000 people were driven out of the city by rising prices.

Even before the 1996 Olympics, Atlanta was one of the most segregated cities in the US. But the games gave the clique of white developers who ran them the excuse to engineer a new ethnic cleansing programme. Without any democratic process they demolished large housing projects (whose inhabitants were mostly African-American) and replaced them with shiny middle-class homes; about 30,000 families were evicted. They issued "quality of life ordinances", which criminalised people who begged or slept rough. The police were given pre-printed arrest citations bearing the words "African-American, Male, Homeless": they just had to fill in the name, charge and date. In the year before the games they arrested 9,000 homeless people. Many were locked up without trial until the games were over; others were harassed until they left the city. By the time the athletes arrived, downtown Atlanta had been cleared for the white middle classes.

In 2002, there was much less persecution of the poor, but the economic legacy was still regressive: house prices in Sydney doubled between 1996 and 2003. No provision was made for social housing in the Olympic village, and there were mass evictions from boarding houses and rented homes, which the authorities did nothing to stop. The old pattern resumed in Athens, where the Olympics were used as an excuse to evict 2,700 Roma, even from places where no developments were planned.

In Beijing 1.25 million people have already been displaced to make way for the games, and another quarter of a million are due to be evicted. Like the people of Seoul, they have been threatened and beaten if they resist. Housing activists have been imprisoned. One man, Ye Guozhu, is currently serving four years for "disturbing social order", and has reportedly been suspended by his arms from the ceiling of his cell and tortured with electric batons. Beggars, vagrants and hawkers have been rounded up and sentenced to "re-education through labour". The authorities are planning to hospitalise mentally ill people so that visitors won't have to see them.

London is about to establish its credentials as a true Olympic city by evicting Gypsies and Travellers from Clays Lane in Newham and Waterden Crescent in Hackney: 430 people will be thrown out of the Clays Lane housing co-op and a 100-year-old allotment will be destroyed to make way for a concrete path that will be used for four weeks. Nine thousand new homes will be built for the games, but far more will be lost to the poor through booming prices, which are rising much faster around the Olympic site than elsewhere in London. The buy-to-let vultures have already landed.

The International Olympic Committee raises no objection to any of this. It lays down rigid criteria for cities hosting the games, but these do not include housing rights. How could they? City authorities want to run the games for two reasons: to enhance their prestige and to permit them to carry out schemes that would never otherwise be approved. Democratic processes can be truncated, compulsory purchase orders slapped down, homes and amenities cleared. The Olympic bulldozer clears all objections out of the way. There can be no debate, no exceptions, no modifications. Everything must go.

None of this is an argument against the Olympic games. It is an argument against moving them every four years. Let them stay in a city where the damage has already been done. And let it be anywhere but here.

· George Monbiot's book Heat: How to Stop the Planet Burning is now out in paperback

www.monbiot.com

rank_95.title: Long on legacy, short on wow
rank_95.text:
This is a very simple building", said Rod Sheard, architect in charge of the design of the London 2012 Olympic stadium. And, I must say, it's hard to disagree. If you like your Olympic stadiums like Beijing's next year, in the guise of a giant and strangely thrilling metal bird's nest, or like Athens's in 2004, in the form of a bucking bronco engineering rollercoaster ride, then the London stadium is unlikely to be your cup of green tea, much less your shot of ouzo.

When Lord Coe unveiled the design yesterday, there was a breathless hush in the close-packed ranks of journalists assembled at the stadium site. You could have heard a hurdle drop. There was, though, no sudden burst of applause, not one "wow!"

London, it seems, is taking no chances. Although described yesterday at the official unveiling, in a cruelly wind-scythed Stratford, as "cutting edge" by the mayor of London, "a new blueprint for building Olympic stadia" by Lord Coe and "stunning" by Tessa Jowell, the Olympics minister, the £496m design looked rather tame and not a little like a conservative version of the sort of thing pop-era architects of the 60s used to dream up in swinging London but never quite got to build.

Fearful of building a Dome mark two, the Olympic committee and its designers, architects HOK Sport and engineers Buro Happold, have come up with an 80,000-seat stadium that - hey presto! - will be cut down to size, to just 25,000 seats, with precious little fuss when the Olympic Games have come and gone. So, the stadium is basically a concrete bowl - the permanent bit - with tiers of temporary seats stacked above it, with the whole caboodle wrapped in plastic sheets shot through with the kind of whizzy digital electronic technology that will allow these short-lived walls to display any images, still or moving, the Olympic committee deems fit for global public consumption in summer 2012. Given over to clever video designers and artists, this could be immense fun, and even illuminating.

Above all, though, this safe, sensible and pragmatic design has clearly been driven by the dreaded "L" word. All six speakers at the press conference used it, with Ms Jowell very probably breaking the world record with three mentions in less than 30 seconds. Not even the dashing Seb Coe could have beaten her. The word is "legacy", all the vogue in the very political circles that shaped the dread Millennium Experience a decade ago.

Sadly, no one holding an official torch for the London Olympics was willing or able to describe this "legacy". Expect, though, a huddled mass of low-cost homes, thrusting, two-fingers-up office blocks, gaudy shopping malls, a splash of artistic "water features" and a quirky new park along the banks of the river Lea in the soft shadow of a small and sensible, all-purpose post-Olympic stadium. The stadium may well go on to host a circus or two, but, matter-of-fact and just a little mousey, this will certainly be no white elephant.

· Jonathan Glancey is the Guardian's architecture critic

rank_71.title: I can work with Coe and deliver London legacy, says Hoey
rank_71.text:
Labour MP Kate Hoey said last night that her appointment as Boris Johnson's Commissioner for Sport would bring a new focus on the sporting legacy of the London Olympics and insisted it would not prevent her working harmoniously with other stakeholders in the project.

Johnson's election and Hoey's appointment mark a sea-change in the attitude of the mayor's office to the Olympics. Ken Livingstone saw the Olympic dividend for London in terms of the regeneration of east London but Johnson is likely to focus on the sporting legacy and on driving down costs.

To this end he will appoint a financial expert to work alongside Hoey as part of his Olympic monitoring team. The former sports minister's appointment is a controversial one, not least because during the bidding process she said Paris deserved the games more than London. Her frequent criticism of government sports policy also antagonised many in the Department for Culture, Media and Sport now involved in the Olympic project and her decision to accept a job from the Conservative mayor has angered some in the Labour party.

Hoey said her role would be to ensure the Olympics left a sporting legacy for London, a clear departure from the regeneration-focused tenure of the previous mayor. She will not officially represent the mayor on the London organising committee board but said she would attend meetings where the sporting legacy is discussed.

Asked if she could foresee tension arising as a result of her appointment Hoey said: "I can't foresee any problems. I think sport is one of those areas where there is the possibility of cross-party involvement. I am in politics to get things done and if that means working with people who have a different party label than me than so be it.

"I can work with Seb [Coe] without any problem. He has a very clearly defined role in that he has to deliver the games for the International Olympic Committee. I am not going to be involved in the financial elements of the Olympics or sidetracked by them. My involvement is really about the sporting legacy and ensuring that when the Olympics have departed that the people of London, be they in Barnet, Croydon or east London have something to show for it.

"There's been a lot of talk about the sporting legacy of the games but there is very little detail and no legacy plan yet. Sport has clearly not been a priority in the project but the new mayor believes that boosting sports participation is as important, if not more important, than regeneration."

Johnson attended his first Olympic board meeting yesterday and he will meet the IOC for the first time next week when they visit London on an annual inspection of progress. His elevation is certain to change the political dynamics of the project. Previously the Olympic board was politically split between Tessa Jowell and Livingstone and the Conservative peers Lord Coe, chairman of the organising committee, and Lord Moynihan, chair of the British Olympic Association.

Coe has resigned the Tory whip and is officially neutral, though in practice he is said to have often endorsed the government position to emphasise his neutrality. Moynihan, meanwhile, has battled for greater financial transparency over the budget and a greater focus on the sporting dividend of the games, often in vain.

With Johnson on the board he will have an ally, and he is close to Hoey having collaborated with her on an independent critique of government sports policy in 2005.

rank_221.title: London 2012 Olympic stadium may not have an athletics legacy after all
rank_221.text:
Boris Johnson's plans for the legacy use of the Olympic stadium in Stratford look like undermining Britain's standing in international sport once again.

Talks over what configuration the main 2012 stadium will have after the Olympics are increasingly distant from a pledge made to the Olympic and athletics governing bodies in 2005. The bid book delivered to the International Olympic Committee in Singapore in 2005 promised it, and the International Association of Athletics Federations, that London would maintain a fit-for-purpose athletics stadium in its East End.

But Johnson, the mayor of London whose London Development Agency has final say over post-Games use of facilities, admitted today that the athletics usage might not transpire.

"I will not dilate for a long time on the legacy prospects of the stadium," said Johnson. "But this is still a story that is not closed; we should look at it and continue to explore all options. There has been considerable private-sector investment into the Bird's Nest [Olympic stadium in Beijing] and the investors hold a 30-year lease over the structure. This is something interesting. There are issues to do with their managing to attract football to the stadium but so far we have failed to do that in London."

The IOC and IAAF trust Stratford's stadium will become a compact, 25,000-seat facility that can hold athletics meets at full capacity. But Britain could become an international pariah again if renewed plans gather pace to bolt an athletics track on to what would be a larger football stadium. Athletics could only ever fill a 40,000-plus-seat venue to capacity during an Olympics; otherwise it would stand half empty.

London's Singapore promise was in itself an attempt to assuage opposition from within the powerful IAAF after London had to withdraw from its hosting of the 2005 world athletics championship over the collapse of the Pickett's Lock stadium project. But since taking over as London's mayor from Ken Livingstone, Johnson has repeatedly insisted cost-savings must be made around the Olympics. And the insertion of a football tenant would certainly be the most viable option.

"It is very, very important to remember that we won the Games at a time of economic plenty and that we must deliver it against a background of a credit crunch, a downturn and a possible recession," said Johnson. "We are seeking economies where we can but that does not mean this will be a penny-pinching, austerity Games. Very considerable savings are being made."

Discussions have not yet been held with the most obvious tenancy candidate, West Ham United, the local football club in the borough of Newham.

rank_209.title: London 2012 Olympics: Boris Johnson vows to create 'massive sporting legacy'
rank_209.text:
Mayor will work with London Development Agency and councils to 'enthuse' and 'inspire' a new generation of children

This article is more than 11 years old

This article is more than 11 years old

Boris Johnson today promised tens of millions of pounds will be spent coaching young people for the 2012 London Olympics to create a "massive sporting legacy".

Speaking to the Evening Standard before he flew home from Beijing after Britain's most successful games, the London mayor told the Evening Standard he was "totally dedicated" to helping the British sporting stars of the future.

Johnson told the London daily: "I want to ring-fence London Development Agency money for sport and that means not just investing in facilities but also investing in the mentoring and the tuition that are so important for long-term success.

"You can have the facilities but if you don't invest in the people to train and give people encouragement, it's not going to work. Sporting opportunity can be part of an early intervention strategy that tackles child poverty and under achievement.

"I hope a new generation of London children will be enthused, inspired and get involved in sport in a way that they're not now."

Johnson will work in partnership with councils to pay for projects as diverse as resurfacing tennis courts, to expanding martial arts clubs in community centres and transporting children to their nearest swimming pools.

Asked whether the LDA investment for sport would be worth tens of millions of pounds, the mayor replied "of course".

A spokesman for the mayor's office told theguardian.com: "No actual figure has been put on this but the LDA will be working with the mayor to deliver his vision."

The Tory mayor's pledge was reinforced by his party, which today promised that a Conservative government would release an extra £58m a year in sports funding as part of its plans to reform the national lottery.

The shadow culture secretary, Jeremy Hunt, said extra sports funding would be achieved by banning lottery cash from being diverted to health and education projects that the Conservatives say should be funded by government.

The Conservatives have vowed to return the national lottery to its original "four pillars" of sport, the arts, heritage and charities.

Hunt said a Conservative government would boost the current £205m annual sports funding by nearly £46.9m.

Another £11.35m would come from a new tax regime for Camelot, the lottery operator.

Hunt said: "The results in Beijing have decisively lifted the curse of dashed expectations that so often hangs over British sport. Now we need to build on this for the future by getting more young people involved in sport.

"Some will do it because they want to be the next Christine Ohuruogu, others just because it is healthy and fun. Our reforms will secure more funding for grassroots sport which has to be the solid foundation on which future sporting success is built."

A spokeswoman for the Department of Culture, Media and Sport said total exchequer investment in sport in England alone has risen from £50m in 1997/98 to £400m in 2007/08 - an increase of over 700%.

"Taken together, total public funding for sport has risen dramatically and totals over £4bn during the last 10 years," the spokeswoman said.

The department also defended lottery spending on projects which fell outside the "four pillars".

The spokeswoman said: "The government has always been committed to the principle that lottery money is additional and will not be allowed to become a substitute for funding that would normally fall to mainstream government spending.

"Community, education and health projects, often delivered by voluntary groups, are as worthy of funding as sports schemes."

rank_125.title: Boris Johnson appoints Carphone Warehouse founder as chief Olympic adviser
rank_125.text:
Carphone Warehouse founder David Ross to head a new team of legacy advisers for the 2012 Olympics

London mayor Boris Johnson has appointed the founder of Carphone Warehouse to head a new team of legacy advisers for the 2012 Olympics.

David Ross will lead a board, which, according to Johnson, will seek to ensure the Olympic Park in Stratford, east London, is "a landmark district of 21st century London" after the games are finished.

Jules Pipe, Labour mayor of Hackney, is among the group of advisers, who will work on transforming the area through a wider sporting, cultural and educational legacy.

The promise of a strong legacy was one of the factors that helped convince the International Olympic Committee to award the games to London.

The panel was set up after Ross, also the mayor's nominee for the board of the London organising committee for the Olympic and Paralympic games, completed a report in June on preparations for the games and their legacy.

He warned that a "perfect storm" of global financial issues, the terror threat, and the rising cost of raw materials could break the £9.3bn budget.

Ross said: "As I noted in my report to the mayor, the long-term future of the Olympic park is probably the most important part of the London 2012 arrangements, but also the most complex."

The board will look at setting up a separate panel in 2009 to secure development and investment, largely from the private sector, for regeneration in and around the Olympic

park.

Johnson said: "The Olympic park can and must be a landmark district of 21st-century London that builds on the electrifying excitement and global recognition of the games themselves. This cannot be achieved without robust business and delivery plans, and a clear understanding of what will inspire private investors to make a long-term commitment to the area."

"I am looking forward enormously to getting started," he added.

Other board members announced today are: David Gregson, part-time chair of private equity group Phoenix Equity Partners; Tessa Sanderson, former Olympic gold medalist and head of the Newham sports academy; Sir Bob Kerslake, chief executive of the new Homes and Communities Agency; Harvey McGrath, chair of Prudential as well as the London Development Agency; Jeremy Newsum, executive trustee of the Grosvenor Estate; Julia Peyton-Jones, director of the Serpentine Gallery; Richard Sharp, non executive chair of the board of Huntsworth Communications group and Neale Coleman, the mayor's adviser on the 2012 games.

* Read Dave Hill's London blog for more on this subject

rank_40.title: 'Olympic university' to be built on site of London games
rank_40.text:
This article is more than 11 years old

This article is more than 11 years old

An "Olympic university" will be established on the site of the London 2012 games in a bid to secure a long-term legacy for the £9.3bn being spent by taxpayers on the event, ministers announced today.

The facility is likely to be built within the media village once the games are over. It is part of a range of education facilities planned for the site that include a sports-focused secondary school in the Olympic stadium, an arts academy in the Olympic village and three new primary schools.

The plans, which were opened to public consultation today, set out proposals to build 10,000 new homes, in addition to 3,000 already being built in the Olympic village.

The mayor of London, Boris Johnson, the communities secretary, Hazel Blears, and Olympics minister, Tessa Jowell, said in a statement that their vision was for "a vibrant, thriving district of new communities surrounded by beautiful parklands and reclaimed waterways, with outstanding sporting, educational and cultural facilities".

They said the main 25,000-seater stadium would be retained to host major international athletics championships, rock concerts and festivals.

The decision seems to have ended plans to recoup some of the cost of the £547m stadium by allowing a football or rugby club to make it their home. Saracens rugby club and Leyton Orient football club had shown interest.

There were also plans for the arena to house the national skills academy for sports and leisure industries, and a centre for the English Institute of Sport.

The aquatics centre and the velodrome would be retained and new football, hockey, tennis and mountain-biking facilities would be built in the park.

Olympics bosses said the plans would deliver 10,000 new jobs, attracting businesses to a new hub around the media and broadcast centre. That is 2,000 fewer than Jowell's legacy action plan, which was written prior to the economic downturn.

rank_96.title: Olympics: 'Dismay' over Woolwich as shooting venue for London 2012
rank_96.text:
London 2012 organisers announced yesterday that shooting events would remain at a temporary venue in Woolwich, provoking an outcry from the sport. British Shooting's chairman, Phil Boakes, reacted with "utter dismay" to the decision, which he said would leave no legacy despite costing more than £40m, and vowed to carry on fighting for an alternative venue at the National Shooting Centre in Bisley.

After a meeting of the Olympic board yesterday, it said that following a feasibility study of two alternative sites in Bisley and Barking, shooting would remain at the Royal Artillery Barracks in Woolwich, south-east London."The Olympic Delivery Authority has conducted a thorough review process of all three locations. However, the board still feels that Woolwich is the best choice of venue," said the chairman of the London Organising Committee of the Olympic Games, Lord Coe.

"It is an iconic venue close to the Olympic Village, with a strong shooting heritage, and is one of the Greenwich cluster of Olympic and Paralympic venues."

The decision, following a three month review that flowed from last year's KPMG audit of all temporary venues, provoked immediate condemnation from Boakes."My reaction is one of utter dismay. This is very, very disappointing," he said. "The main thing is that there is no legacy for shooting now. This is more than £40m of public money being spent and there will be nothing to show for it after 2012. This is not about sport, it's about politics."

But organisers claim the alternative venues would have been even more expensive and that Woolwich remained the most cost-effective option. Ranges, targets and other infrastructure would be reused, said LOCOG.

Organisers argue that the logistical challenges and extra costs required to upgrade Bisley and provide athlete accommodation on the site make it prohibitively expensive.

Yesterday's decision leaves the only outstanding question mark over 2012 venues around a temporary structure on the Greenwich Peninsula slated to host badminton and other sports. A decision will be made later this year on whether to build it or move the events to Wembley or Excel.Meanwhile the ODA and Locog will also have to overcome opposition from some likely participants and local residents over the decision to host equestrian events in Greenwich Park. Zara Phillips is among those who have criticised the decision, which will not leave any legacy facilities.

rank_127.title: World Cup bid success could keep Olympic stadium at 80,000 capacity
rank_127.text:
The main London 2012 stadium may not be downsized after the Olympic Games, with the capital's mayor now hoping it will stage World Cup football matches if England's bid for the 2018 tournament is successful. Boris Johnson had previously said it would be too expensive to retain the stadium's maximum capacity of 80,000 and had backed plans for the venue to be reduced to 25,000.

"I'd be very foolish to rule it out now," said Johnson today. With Olympic organisers unable to find a football club to take residence in the stadium after 2012 it is estimated that the £547m development could cost £10m annually to maintain. But with England bidding for the World Cup in 2018, Johnson hopes the Stratford site could become one of the 12 designated venues.

Similarly the Olympic Stadium could also stage matches if the International Rugby Board selects England as the host of the 2015 Rugby World Cup on 28 July.

"It's a very difficult technical subject, but anyone with any common sense looking at this wonderful venue we are constructing in Stratford will say, 'Why not?'" said Johnson.

"It adds hugely to the attractions of London. London already boasts fantastic, incomparable sporting facilities. We are already a leading contender to have the 2018 World Cup and I think the stadium in the Olympic Park is well worth considering as an additional venue."

Arsenal's Emirates Stadium and Tottenham's planned new venue alongside White Hart Lane are also in contention to stage World Cup matches in London.

Retaining the Stratford site as an 80,000-seat venue received key backing last week from Margaret Ford, who has become the head of the Olympic legacy board. Members of the London Assembly plan to press the mayor on how much it would cost to keep the stadium at 50,000 capacity, if not 80,000.

"We have a very interesting passage of argument ahead of us and Margaret Ford, who has just taken over as the chairman of the Olympic Park legacy company, has been absolutely right to raise this issue up the agenda – to look at the possibility of keeping the stadium going beyond 2012, 2013," said Johnson.

"I'm not going to say that's been decided because that would be wrong. But it's certainly something that people with common sense are going to look at."

Earlier this year, the London Development Agency said the stadium cannot make money or break even after the Olympics and would be subsidised by the rest of east London's Olympic Park.

After the Olympics, the stadium will house a secondary school for about 500 students, the National Skills Academy for sports and leisure industries and the English Institute of Sport.

rank_243.title: Tessa Jowell disputes mayor's claims over 2012 Olympic Stadium legacy
rank_243.text:
Tessa Jowell contradicted Boris Johnson, the mayor of London, today by claiming that the Olympic Stadium will be downsized after 2012 and will not be a potential venue for the 2018 World Cup. The Olympics minister ruled out the prospect of a Premier League club using the stadium but remains hopeful that a commercial tenant will be found.

"We don't need another football stadium, we have got Wembley," said Jowell, speaking at the Beyond Sport summit in Central London. "Funding the maintenance of a stadium between 2012 and 2018 is quite a stretch, so I think we will continue to develop the plan that we have for the Olympic Stadium."

Johnson said last week that it would be "very foolish to rule out" retaining at least a 50,000 capacity as England bids to host the 2018 World Cup but Jowell said organisers were committed to honouring their pledge to provide Britain with a 25,000-seat athletics venue. Sir Keith Mills, vice-chairman of 2012 and non-executive director of the 2018 bid, concurred that it "would not be economically viable" to retain the 80,000-seat Olympic Stadium.

The Olympic Legacy Committee, headed by Lady Margaret Ford and set up to oversee the Olympic project, was said to be examining the prospect of retaining a 50,000-capacity for the Stratford venue but Jowell reaffirmed continuity with the original plan that gained London the right to host the Games, in 2005.

"We made a very clear commitment in the bid book that the Olympic Stadium in legacy will be a 20- to 25,000-seater athletics stadium with the provision for a warm-up track so that London and indeed the UK will have a grand prix athletics stadium," she added. "There is no Premier League football club with which we are in discussion about their long-term use of the Olympic Stadium.

The only confirmed tenants of the stadium are the English Institute of Sport and the National Skills Academy for Sport and Leisure, a "concentration of sporting organisations promoting excellence" that Jowell said will provide a "fantastic legacy" for the stadium.

However, the minister is still hopeful that further commercial parties can be attracted in the wake of the Olympics: "We are] probably four years away from the point when a new tenant will move into the stadium, probably more," she said. "In the current commercial environment it is quite a big ask to say, 'Will you sign a contract for five years hence?'"

Also attending the summit was the former prime minister Tony Blair, who said that, despite the economic downturn, he had absolutely no regrets that the London bid was successful. He does not see the stadium as the Games' greatest legacy but rather the impetus they can give to sport at a lower level.

"The stadium is something you have and the facilities. That's great but, let's be clear, it's still a relatively small number of people that will have access to that," he said. "I think the important thing is to use it as a galvaniser for grass-roots sport. That's to me what will make the difference."

rank_257.title: Urgent thinking is underway about long-term 2012 Olympic legacy
rank_257.text:
My regular mid-month visit to the Olympic Stadium and Park was even less mid-month than usual. Still, my failure to make the excursion until yesterday did mean it coincided with this year's 2012 Open Weekend and the special event on the Greenway. See what I saw, taking particular note of the Lyle's Golden Syrup artwork.

The yellow structure is temporary, though it was explained that the big bit will be a semi-permanent facility catering to site visitors (I think). The part of the Greenway beyond it, connecting up to Stratford High Street is closed off (pdf) until next spring while a stretch of road that runs beneath it is lowered. The big news since last time, though, is that the stadium's outer shell has been officially deemed complete. Meanwhile, the curvaceous skeleton of the aquatic centre - which ODA chairman John Armitt is particularly excited about - looks fully formed. For a good if fleeting view of it, take a North London Line train into Stratford station.

With three years to go, the permanent buildings seem to be rising from the dust on time. It's still not clear, however, what will happen to the stadium once August 2012 has been and gone. The original plan to reduce capacity from 80,000 to 25,000 is now under scrutiny. At Boris's public consultation meeting in Walthamstow last month Labour peer Baroness Margaret Ford, who chairs the newly-formed Olympic Legacy Delivery Company, said she wanted the stadium to be for both "community and elite sports" after the Games and that the trick was to "get the balance right." In a subsequent interview she spoke of retaining the 80,000 capacity, seeing the stadium as a potential 2018 World Cup venue. In this she's sharing a hymn sheet efficiently with Seb Coe, who's now contributing to the England World Cup bid.

It's a tough circle - well, more of an oval - to square. Someone else with the matter on his mind is Dalston-dweller Andrew Boff AM, who speaks on the issue for the Assembly Conservatives. He's asked Mayor Johnson what it would cost to have the stadium's "legacy capacity" increased to 50,000. He's yet to receive an answer, and I predict that when he does it will be cagey.

The Football Association will settle on which stadiums to include in its bid at the end of this year. By then, Baroness Ford will hope to have come up with a major "visitor attraction" for the post-Games park, saying at the Walthamstow meeting that she'd be visiting local schools to seek ideas. She's got plenty else to think about too. As her fellow Walthamstow panelist Hackney's Mayor Jules Pipe put it, the legacy area in its entirety will be like half an additional London borough constructed in the space of just 20-odd years. Boris, of course, mustered an extravagant metaphor, describing the Games as "a beast of burden that we can lasso to drive change and improvement."

The sheer scale of the enterprise is, indeed, gigantic. When pausing on my bike ride back home along the River Lea I tried to imagine it all fully-formed, stretching away southwards down the Lea Valley. I'll be a pensioner by the time it's finished. I look forward to visiting it in a handsome New Routemaster, travelling free thanks to my Freedom Pass, and thinking of the former Mayor Johnson, wherever and whatever he may be by then.

rank_244.title: Games tsar to ensure legacy of London 2012 Olympics
rank_244.text:
The government is to counter criticism that it is failing to deliver on the promises that helped win the 2012 Olympic Games for London by appointing a "sports legacy tsar", to get more people participating in sport and help attract private sector investment.

Ministers are looking for a high-profile figure who could be a former Olympic athlete or an influential name who has experience of running a sporting body.

With the Olympic flame due to be lit in the new stadium in Stratford, east London, three years from tomorrow, there is increasing optimism that organisers will deliver the games on time and within the £9.3bn budget, despite the impact of the recession. But opposition MPs and senior sports figures have told the Guardian that there remain serious questions over the legacy of the 2012 Games. In particular, there are concerns over promises to use the Olympics to increase sporting activity and fight obesity.

Critics claim that "four years have been wasted" in devising a strategy to deliver on the promise of getting 1 million people taking part in more sport by 2012 and a broader pledge to get 1 million more participating in physical activity, including walking and gardening.

Organisations including the British Olympic Association and the CCPR (Central Council of Physical Recreation), which represents hundreds of governing bodies, have voiced concerns that plans to use the Olympics to make a "once in a lifetime" change in the population's sporting habits are yet to have any impact at grassroots level. The shadow sports minister, Hugh Robertson, said: "The lack of a proper strategy for delivering our participation promises is the single biggest problem with the Olympics."

The Liberal Democrat Olympic spokesman, Tom Brake, said "alarm bells must be ringing in government", which "may have bitten off more than it can chew". The CCPR chair, Brigid Simmonds, added: "We have been saying for some time that the Olympics will have a long sunrise and a very short sunset. If we don't get it right, this huge opportunity will be lost. With three years to go, let's grasp it and let's get on with it." In response, it is understood that the sports minister, Gerry Sutcliffe, who remains confident that the targets can be achieved, plans to convene a new team led by a "legacy tsar" to co-ordinate sport participation.

The government believes that it has put all the necessary building blocks in place, including getting the various agencies working harmoniously and doubling sports funding in the three years since 2005, but acknowledges that a more co-ordinated national approach is required.

"Some regions are getting on and doing it and others are sitting back and waiting for something to happen," Sutcliffe said. "It's got to be about inspiration as well. The athletes need to be out in their communities inspiring people."

It will also co-ordinate a drive to get private backers involved in the legacy push. Adidas will announce that it is rolling out its "sportszone" concept around the country following a trial in London, and there are hopes that other Olympic sponsors will want to get involved with legacy projects. Figures released last week by Sport England, the body charged with delivering the 1 million participation increase and investing £480m of lottery and public funds in grassroots sport between 2009 and 2013, revealed that progress appeared to have stalled.

Quarterly figures showed that of 31 sports measured according to how many people played them at least once a week, only table tennis recorded an increase. Nine - including swimming, football, gymnastics and rowing - showed a decline and the rest showed no change.

In order to achieve its target, Sport England must boost the 6.8 million people playing sport for 30 minutes at least three times a week by 1 million. The other 1 million, to be delivered through other government agencies including the National Health Service, must be doing some form of physical activity for 30 minutes at least three times a week. Sport England argues that the quarterly survey is merely a guide and that the next annual survey, due in December, will give a clearer idea of progress under a plan launched earlier this year to invest the bulk of its lottery and public funds directly through sport governing bodies.

It was partly the bold legacy promises made by London Organising Committee chairman, Seb Coe, that the Olympics would transform the East End of London, inspire a generation of young people through sport and deliver health benefits for the entire nation that helped convince International Olympic Committee members to vote for the city in 2005.
