rank_167.title: Olympic legacy: how the six Olympic boroughs compare for children
rank_167.text:
Ho healthy are the children in the six inner London boroughs hosting the Olympics - and what are their prospects?

The London Health Observatory - which provides unrivalled access to health statistics across the capital, reports that, writes James Meikle today

The health and life chances of children in the six London boroughs hosting the Olympics deteriorate significantly by the time they reach their teens, according to an NHS assessment setting a baseline for whether there is a lasting legacy for those living on the Games' doorstep. While there are already signs of progress in areas such as antenatal care and infant health, high proportions of five-year-olds are obese and only just over half are ready for school

Here are some of the key facts:

• In four of the six boroughs, six to 12-year-olds are less physically active than elsewhere in London

• A higher number of 13 to 18-year-olds in Tower Hamlets and Waltham Forest smoke than the average for London

• Young people in Newham and Waltham Forest have more first-time court appearances

• Just over half of all school leavers in the boroughs – the others are Hackney, Newham, and Barking and Dagenham – achieve five GCSEs, significantly worse than the London average

• Teenagers are less likely to be in education, employment or training. By the age of 18, the conception rate in all boroughs bar Tower Hamlets is above the capital's average

The issue is important: more than a quarter of the population of the boroughs is under 20. Three-quarters of five to 16-year-olds are from black or ethnic minority backgrounds and the proportion living in poverty ranges from a third in Greenwich and Waltham Forest to more than half in Tower Hamlets. The London average is just under 30%.

The report builds off the back of the early years' evidence from the Marmot Review of Health Inequalities in England: Fair society, healthy lives. Its aim is to "give every child the best start in life and enable children, young people and adults to maximise their potential."

rank_59.title: Live Q&A: The Olympic legacy for the voluntary sector, Tuesday 24 July
rank_59.text:
Join our panel, from 12pm to 2pm , to discuss how London 2012 will challenge and develop the voluntary sector

The London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games will recruit upto 70,000 Games Makers, many of whom will be volunteering for the first time. As Jean Tomlin, HR director at Locog, writes on the network this week, volunteers "are the lifeblood of London 2012" and "without them, the Olympics simply wouldn't happen."

This presents a huge opportunity for charities, many of whom rely on volunteers. In wider terms for the voluntary sector, almost half of the UK's largest charities are optimistic that the games will have a positive impact on the voluntary sector and on their individual charity.

However, the big challenge will be to make this impact a lasting one, once the games have finished.

With this in mind our Q&A this week will cover:

• How charities can get involved in London 2012

• How the Olympics could change the voluntary sector

• How charities can make the most of the Olympic legacy

• What the Games Maker programme can teach the sector about volunteer management

You can leave your views and questions in the comments section below, or come back to join the discussion live from 12pm to 2pm on Tuesday 24 July. To join our experts on the panel, email Abby Young-Powell.

Expert panel

rank_77.title: London legacy: bridge-building in Hackney Wick
rank_77.text:
The Hackney Wick Village barbecue area beside the River Lea Navigation Canal. Photograph: Dave Hill

Residents of Wick Village in the Hackney Wick area of east Hackney, can look across the River Lea Navigation Canal from the walkway along the side of it and see the blank face of the Olympic Park press centre looking back. It didn't used to be that way. Before the vast 2012 land clearance began their view was of a green space known as Arena Fields, which lay just to the south of the legendary Hackney Marshes.

Then came years of construction work, bringing with it noise, dust, inconvenience and some distress to the village and other residential areas nearby. The consolation, say Wick Villagers Dee O'Connell and Ian White, was a promise by the Olympic Delivery Authority (ODA) that the walkway and a grassy, tree-lined continuation of it that runs behind the playground wall of neighbouring Gainsborough primary school would be improved for communal benefit.

The little stretch behind the school is of particular importance to the residents, not all of whom have gardens. A secure future of secluded waterfront barbecues was envisaged, restoring the space for the use it was put to until around 2010 when vandals damaged the lighting, making the space unsafe. But Dee, Ian and, it seems, many of their neighbours fear that the walkway and erstwhile barbecue spot will instead become a public thoroughfare serving one end of a footbridge that would span the canal and provide public access to the post-Games park.

What we have here is a hyperlocal tale that illuminates larger issues about the benefits or otherwise to local communities of the Olympic Park's development in the years to come, and how those issues are managed by the powers that be.

It's a tricky situation. There's a strong argument for building a bridge. The catering building serving the press centre and the much larger broadcast centre behind it will be demolished after the Games to make way for new playing fields for the fast-expanding Gainsborough school, and these would eventually be shared with a new school on the park side of the canal serving one of the park's eventual new neighbourhoods. The bridge would replace one that had previously connected the school to the opposite bank, until it fell into disrepair and was demolished four years ago.

The Wick Village objectors recognise this need for the bridge, but think it should terminate within Gainsborough school's playground - as the old one did - and be for pupils' use alone. It's the possibility of general public access that worries them. Dee and Ian are young, relative newcomers but say that many fellow residents who've lived there since Wick Village was built in the early 1990s - and in some cases in the tower blocks it replaced - are elderly, frail and worried that their quiet niche will become a place that droves of park visitors pass through or, worse, that antisocial elements hang about in.

There's a complicated backstory here. The original planning application for a new bridge was approved in 2007, under the first Olympic Park masterplan. It was drawn up with Gainsborough school's needs principally in mind, but included a provision for the bridge to possibly become accessible to the general public at a later date.

The London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC), now the planning authority for the park and some surrounding areas, explains that it has inherited this planning permission and is legally obliged to abide by it. However, it stresses that this doesn't mean that the bridge will be accessible to the public straight away or indeed ever, only that consideration of "how public access could be facilitated in the future," would be included in the determination of the application its has submitted to the ODA jointly with Hackney Council. It adds that there would be consultation with residents if and when the process of making the bridge accessible to the public went ahead.

But this doesn't meet the objectors' fears. They say that not only would the possibility of full public access remain but that designing the bridge in a way that would allow for this in the future would cause them a separate problem by intruding on the barbecue area. An access ramp would be installed along the outside wall of the playground they say, taking up a wide strip of the space and requiring the removal of the trees along that side of it.

Another twist in the dispute is that some of the original residents say that the barbecue area was bought from British Waterways at the time of Wick Village's birth by the tenant management organisation, which is responsible for some aspects of its running, including repairing it and keeping it clean. However, no formal records of such a purchase seem to exist.

Hackney Council applied successfully for "adverse possession" of the land in 2010 (under the same legislation that grants rights to squatters). I understand that it and LLDC consider that they've minimised the space the access ramp would take up and would undertake to re-position or replace the existing barbecue facilities, plants and seating as well as instal a railing on the canal side to make it safer for people using the area.

A public access bridge is also included in Hackney's planning policy for the area, the Hackney Wick area action plan and there have been public consultations on that. But whatever the pros and cons of the actual proposals, an underlying problem of trust seems to remain. Dee and Ian say there's a feeling among residents that the ODA and Hackney Council haven't always made clear enough to what the implications of the bridge for Wick Village might be, and are now not being as helpful as they should.

At least 34 of Wick Village's 120 households have sent off written objections to the proposals, which have been submitted for determination to the relevant committees of the ODA and Hackney Council on, respectively, 23 July and 12 September. This is not at all the situation they thought they'd up in back when thought something would be done to make up for all the disruption and change that has occurred.

A closing thought. This might be a very small, very local Olympics legacy story, but, whatever has gone before, the authorities should do all in their power to bring about an ending to it that leaves local people as happy as possible. That, after all, is what legacy is meant to do, and not only in Wick Village.

rank_220.title: Live discussion: regeneration and the London 2012 Olympics
rank_220.text:
Join our panel of experts from 12pm on Monday 23 July to discuss what makes a successful scheme project and what we can hope for from the Olympic legacy

More than 11,000 new homes will be built on the site of the Olympic Park in what London mayor Boris Johnson has described as "the most important regeneration project for the next 25 years".

The 202-hectare (500-acre) site will be handed over to the London Legacy Development Corporation after the Games and work will begin work on the area's transformation. When it re-opens in 2013, 40% of the properties will be family homes with three or four bedrooms, and 35% will be reserved for affordable housing.

Demand for the properties is high. The waiting list for subsidised housing in the East Village is already oversubscribed, according to Triathlon Homes, the housing association which will manage 1,379 homes in the new community.

Despite optimism in London, British urban renegeration projects have a chequered history. Though some have reinvigorated neighbourhoods in decline, others have only succeeded in making a bad situations worse.

The Commonwealth Games provided the opportunity for the regeneration of east Manchester which saw the construction of almost 5,000 new homes and the renovation of more than 6,000 existing properties – resulting in a 400% increase in local house prices.

Yet elsewhere in Manchester, and across the north of England and the Midlands, the government's decision to axe the housing market renewal project four years early has left a trail of boarded-up ghost towns instead of the regenerated communities originally planned.

Just a few miles away from the Olympic site rise the skyscrapers of Canary Wharf, another of London's major urban regeneration areas and the subject of an ongoing, heated debate over its impact on east Londoners.

So what are the crucial ingredients for successful urban regeneration? How can we make the most out of the Olympic Park site and what can be learned from previous projects?

Join our panel of experts from 12pm on Monday 23 July to take part in the discussion, or leave a comment in advance now.

Panel

Duncan Innes is executive director of real estate at the London Legacy Development Corporation. Before joining the Olympic Park Legacy Company in May 2010, Duncan was head of programmes with the Homes and Communities Agency and director of strategic land with English

Partnerships

Olaide Oyekanmi is head of sales and marketing at Triathlon Homes, the company that owns 1,379 of the 2,818 homes at the Olympic Village after the London 2012 Olympic and Paralympic Games. Triathlon Homes comprises East Thames, Southern Housing and private developer, First Base

Dave Smith is community organiser (housing) for Citizens UK. He has three years experience as a community organiser, chiefly based in east London, and also leads Citizen UK's housing work in relation to the Olympic Legacy Park

Conor McAuley is executive member for regeneration and strategic planning and has been an elected member of Newham council since 1982. His roles have included deputy leader of the council and chair of Newham's planning committee and he represented the borough on the board of the London Docklands Development Corporation. He is also currently vice-chair of the Thames Gateway London Partnership and a member of the Olympic Delivery Authority's Planning Committee

Dave Adamson is chief executive of the Centre of Regeneration Excellence in Wales (Crew). Dave has extensive experience of research, evaluation and policy development in regeneration related areas and has worked with a wide range of regeneration partners. Dave has published widely in the field of area-based regeneration and has conducted research for the Joseph Rowntree Foundation on area-based regeneration in all UK devolved regions

Mark Dutton is head of regeneration at the Vela Group, a north-east housing group formed as a result of a partnership between social landlords Tristar Homes and Housing Hartlepool. It has more than 17,000 homes and 700 employees.

Caroline Field is regeneration manager for Orbit Homes. She is currently managing the regeneration of Larner Road, a high rise estate in Erith, Bexley.

Anabel Palmer is director of social and economic regeneration at Southern Housing Group. Anabel has worked in housing for over 20 years and, over the last 10, has focused on social and economic regeneration and developing projects that support and create opportunity for individuals and communities within social housing. Southern Housing Group is the lead on community development for Triathlon Homes.

rank_179.title: Top tips: regeneration and the Olympic legacy for London
rank_179.text:
We've collected all the best advice from our live discussion on regeneration and the Olympic Games. Share your thoughts in the comments thread

Duncan Innes is executive director of real estate at the London Legacy Development Corporation (LLDC)

Family housing: A key issue, certainly for the Olympic Park itself, is to provide family homes and the social infrastructure (such as schools) that goes with them. We see families and the balanced, stable communities they tend to create as a key building block of our regeneration strategy.

Affordability: For the affordable homes there will be a range of rent levels. Certainly not all of them will be at 80% of market rent.

Dave Smith is a community organiser for Citizens UK

Reintegration: In many ways, I think it is a question of how quickly and ably the LLDC, Newham council and local residents in Leyton and Stratford are able to reconnect with a piece of neighbourhood which has been shut off from their immediate doorstep for a long time. I'd argue that folk currently living in the areas immediately bordering the park will be the ultimate test for the legacy. Will it be something they feel they own and can afford to engage with? Or a new piece of city for a new clientele?

Rethinking prejudices: It is too easy to be immediately prejudicial towards large-scale regeneration efforts and unfair, in the case of this one, to presume that local people and municipal bodies necessarily want different things.

Compromises: What does make people despondent is the feeling of disenfranchisement when their interests are, as they must be from time to time, weighed up against wider financial needs.

Let's be upfront about the term 'affordable': In east London, 80% of the market rate is not affordable. And paradoxically it becomes even less affordable if the rest of the scheme is a "success" and house prices go up. Now if we were to base affordable lets and for-sale homes on people's incomes, rather than a proportion of the market rate, wouldn't that be something unique for London 2012 to be proud of?

Conor McAuley is executive member for regeneration and strategic planning at Newham council

Family housing has not been forgotten: 40% of the homes planned in the legacy communities scheme are intended for families. But if left just to the market, family housing will not be built. This government's desire to simplify the planning system must not be allowed to sweep away the planning policies that are designed to meet local housing needs. Its really is not just about housing numbers, its about family housing and sustainable communities too.

Collaboration is crucial: The success of the East Village post-games will really depend upon some serious joined-up working involving the council, the landlords, Triathlon Homes and Delancy, the Chobham Academy, the NHS and the LLDC. This is placemaking on a scale not attempted since the era of the post war new towns. Except this is in the middle of London, so the local links to the existing communities and networks will be crucial.

Housing is crucial, but people also need jobs: The temptation to see the regeneration of east London simply in terms of the number and type of new homes needed, plus the required social infrastructure such as schools and doctors, really must be resisted.

Understanding the needs of the employers: Over the years, Newham council has been frustrated in the failure of successive regeneration programmes to successfully link local people to the new jobs. Five years age we created Workplace, our own council-funded job brokerage. In the last 12 months, 5,000 Newham residents have obtained employment with more than 2,000 obtaining full time employment at the new Westfield shopping centre.

Olaide Oyekanmi is head of sales and marketing at Triathlon Homes

Using social media: We have already started this with the East Village Facebook page, Twitter and the London Living blog. We also intend to develop an online community for residents before they move in. We believe that this will help to develop relationships and ideas that can be delivered within the east village community once they move in.

David Adamson is chief executive of the Centre for Regeneration Excellence in Wales

Postcode inequality: One of the problems with past regeneration schemes has been rigid boundaries creating postcode inequalities. Permeable boundaries encourage organic development and integrate older communities with new developments.

Mark Dutton is head of regeneration at the Vela Group

Qualitative outcomes: It's important to capture and recognise the true and lasting value of qualitative outcomes around the local sense of place. What do the people living there feel about it? How has life changed for them? What has happened to local aspirations and external perceptions of the area? What about increased opportunities?

Caroline Field is regeneration manager for Orbit Homes

Community integration: We need to make sure that we not focused on building a stand alone community among new residents but forging links with the surrounding communities too. This ensures that the benefits are spread to surrounding areas as well as letting existing community infrastructure creep into the new development. It's much easier to invite in existing community groups and encourage them to expand than it is to start them up from scratch.

Local involvement: One way of building links with surrounding communities is to have some of the people with established local links moving into the new neighbourhood. Sometimes these are people looking to move into home ownership or trade up and still keep their local links, and there have often not been opportunities to buy what they want locally before the regeneration.

Anabel Palmer is director of social and economic regeneration at Southern Housing Group

Bridging new and old communities: The current housing element of the scheme is part of a much wider offer to the local area: great new sports facilities, a new park, new school and health facilities. These will all be accessible to local communities and will be a hub for the new community as well as a bridge between new and existing communities.

rank_128.title: London 2012: The hidden Olympic legacy
rank_128.text:
Getting to see Legacy, the new installation by musician and artist Nick Franglen, is an unusually cloak-and-dagger business. Potential appointments come and go until, on the Monday afternoon before the Olympics, Franglen sends me a last-minute text. Can I come to a station in London's Docklands for 11 o'clock at night? I'm advised to wear boots and dark clothing that I don't mind being ripped.

The reason for all this subterfuge is the venue: a derelict, partially demolished factory that serves as a document to Docklands' industrial past. It is dangerous and guarded at the best of times, let alone during the Olympic build-up.

Franglen first came here four years ago with some urban explorers, intrepid types who infiltrate parts of the city that are abandoned and off-limits. The phrase was coined in 1996 and the internet has since enabled a worldwide network of urban explorers to swap stories, photographs and advice. In January, Franglen decided that the building would be the perfect venue for an idea that had germinated two months earlier, when he was asked to design a piece of sound art for the British Business Embassy, a networking initiative, and felt that he had caught a glimpse of "the beast behind the Olympics".

"I've always liked the Olympics," he says, "but when you've got Jeremy Hunt saying we've decided not to have an austerity Olympics, we mustn't hold back, when we're cutting the School Sports Initiative, that's an interesting conundrum. Legacy is a ghastly word. Politicians talk about the legacy of the games to east London and I think what they're concerned about is what their legacy will be. Does east London benefit from all this regeneration or is it negative to have this completely alien infrastructure dropped into it and its heritage stripped out? I was trying to ask a question: what sort of Olympics do we really want? Why does it have to be like this?"

Franglen is a big, garrulous man but clearly has a steely, obsessive streak. Born in north London, he is best-known as half of chill-out duo Lemon Jelly and producer of albums by John Cale and Badly Drawn Boy. In recent years, however, his projects have become more unorthodox. With his band Blacksand, he has played gigs in such unlikely venues as a mine, a submarine and Pyestock, the former Concorde test centre in Hampshire, beloved of urban explorers. He has also played 24-hour solo theremin concerts beneath Manhattan Bridge and London Bridge.

Legacy, however, is his most ambitious and taxing endeavour yet. He had initially hoped to conclude the installation by watching the opening ceremony fireworks from the building's roof but he has heard rumours that snipers will be stationed there during the games. "I don't mind playing cat-and-mouse with security but I don't want to interfere with people doing a serious job," he says. Also, he adds, "I don't want to be shot."

It's a warm, clear night. We rendezvous in the street and make our way through the outer layer of security. He can never be entirely sure he will get in. "When I approach here my stomach's churning," he admits. "I'm white with fear."

Up close, the building's hulk looms vast and ghostly. Watching out for security patrols, we negotiate a series of fences and enter through a concealed opening. Inside, it is a disaster area. Several floors are gone. Those that remain are Swiss-cheesed with holes where machinery has been removed, covered by rotting boards too flimsy to support anybody's weight. A powerful torch might attract attention so we proceed using only the dim light coming through the broken windows. I follow Franglen's whispered advice: keep close to this wall, mind that loose step, watch out for that 20-foot plunge. "This is not a building to fall over in," he says. "It's a shocker. You could fall and kill yourself, of course, but worse than that you could break your leg in the basement where you can't get a phone signal and no one would ever find you. The first time I came here on my own I found that terrifying, but I feel that this is my domain now. I doubt anyone knows this place as well as I do."

To safely enter the section that houses Legacy you have to climb a ladder across a dizzying drop and scoot across a stretch of scrub that's in full view of a mysterious black dirigible that stealthily patrols the waterfront at unpredictable intervals. Finally, there is the so-called "Leap of Faith". Not, as a rule, having much faith in leaping, I'm relieved to find that it's actually another ladder. "It doesn't live up to its name," agrees Franglen as he clambers down onto the concrete floor. "I call it the Pace of Disappointment."

The building has a pungent, mushroomy aroma and a series of metal staircases and ladders that make our ascent feel reminiscent of a game of Donkey Kong. One room has no outside wall, so it is plastered with guano and noisy with the sound of pigeons' wings. Another is carpeted with hundreds of tangled cables. Franglen points to two industrial fans. "They didn't used to be that close together. Sometimes you notice people have moved things." Urban explorers endeavour to leave minimal trace – they are trespassers, not vandals or burglars – but Franglen has been here often enough to notice the small things. Like many old buildings, it makes strange noises, as if turning in its sleep and muttering to itself. When you're not supposed to be there, these noises can sound uncannily like footsteps.

Eventually we reach the seventh floor, which houses Legacy 1. It's a small garden containing rows of lettuce, spinach, spring onions and radishes, watered by the rain seeping through a hole in the roof. Franglen obtained the seeds from a friend who used to have a plot on the Manor Gardens allotments before they were destroyed to make way for the Olympic Park. That was the easy bit. He used to have to enter the site through a hole in the perimeter fence, and heft sacks of compost across several hundred yards of scrubland. One night he had to climb a tree with two sacks and hide there for four hours. "I used to pray for rain because it meant [the security guard] would stay in his car but, remarkably, it's always been a night like this."

In another room we find Legacy 3: a battery-powered television screening a DVD of the opening ceremony of the Athens Olympics. Franglen intended to contrast the triumphal spectacle with the fact that 21 of the 22 venues built for the games now lie empty. "All these buildings in Athens are derelict and guarded and you're in a derelict, guarded building," he explains. He turns on the TV. In the gloom and hush it seems deafeningly loud and bright, so he quickly clicks it off again.

Legacy 2 is a low roof filled with shallow water, which Franglen has transformed into a miniature boating lake. He smuggled in 205 solar-powered toy rowing boats – one for each nation competing in the Olympics – and, after much trial and error, successfully waterproofed them. "Sainsbury's sandwich bags," he says, proudly holding one up.

We climb another ladder on to the upper roof and I'm suddenly aware that the building is an island of darkness amid a sea of electric light. Behind us lies City airport; to our left the gleaming shells of the Thames barrier; ahead of us the hedgehog spikes of the O2 dome; further to the right the winking eye of Canary Wharf; beyond that the violet glow of the Olympic stadium and the flashing red of Anish Kapoor's Orbit tower. "It's just so beautiful up here," says Franglen, exhaling. "And so quiet, and so secret."

Such hard-earned views are a key incentive for urban explorers, but Franglen doesn't consider himself one of them. "I'm not really a group person," he says. We're sitting on the roof, conversing in low murmurs, like David Attenborough trying not to spook a herd of antelope. "I like coming to these places at night, which means you see the sunrise and get a sense of the building waking up. It's about connecting with the space. These spaces talk to you in some way. Once you've done it, the world feels like a different place."

After his first reconnaissance trip in January, he was apprehensive about starting work until, one night, he was on his way back from a gig and spontaneously thought, "Now. Let's do it now." He has been coming regularly ever since. His original plan was to finish it by May and leave it as an installation for urban explorers. "I was thrilled by the thought of someone discovering it and going, what the hell is this? They'd take photographs and discuss it and it would grow, the same way the plants are growing." But the heightened security associated with the Queen's jubilee and the Olympics has slowed him down and kept most visitors away. Now, he says, this article, and a documentary filmed by a friend, will be Legacy's only exposure to the public. "It's been cut off at the knees," he says sadly.

We hear approaching rotor blades, and crouch, unmoving, beside the low wall that borders the roof. "It's interesting what one gets scared of," he continues after the helicopter has passed overhead. "For the past few weeks I've woken up every morning with a nightmare and it's never about being caught. It's about not being able to get in and complete what I've been trying to do."

I wonder about the kind of person who commits to something like this: all those moments of panic and long hours of solitude. The politics and the artistic challenge don't quite explain it. "It's pretty obviously an obsession," Franglen admits. He used to be a committed motorcyclist until a serious accident in 1998; now he's into scuba diving and cave diving. The goal is always the liberation that comes from intense concentration, when everything melts away but the task at hand. Legacy has had the same effect.

"There's been a point to doing it, and the point isn't just about what's going on in Stratford. It's about what's going on in here." He taps his head. "Once I've delivered that to myself I need to get on with my life. I haven't had much of a life for the past few months. It's all I've thought about." He sighs. "I've been mauled by it. It should have been so much easier. But I've still done it."

Three days later, Franglen emails me to say that Legacy is finished, the last boat (dedicated to Team GB) waterproofed. Out of the blue, a friend who lived locally asked for a tour and became Legacy's fourth and final witness. Then Franglen said goodbye to his temporary domain. "It felt like the fitting final celebration," he writes. "It was always meant to be shared in some way."

Up on the roof on Monday night, however, he knows none of this. As we stand enjoying the view before our descent, something wonderful happens. The sky above the stadium suddenly explodes with a succession of pyrotechnic blooms: a rehearsal for the fireworks display that Franglen will miss. His face brightens with pure delight. "Isn't that fantastic?" he says, gazing into the night. "What a gift!"

rank_229.title: The London Olympics has much to delight – but forget any talk of a legacy
rank_229.text:
The Olympic Games is fine. The facilities at Stratford are as good as ever. The park, the flowers, the "Henman hill" are a delight. The opening was appropriately zany. Above all, television's celebration of youthful energy – when spared the endless BBC chat – is a diversion from the woes of the world. Nor is it fair to chide the athletes for Locog's incompetence, soldiers packing empty seats, public school bias or the weird plutocrats of the "Olympic family", whom I saw yesterday tumbling out of our limousines into Harrods.

So is it worth £9bn? No, of course not. The Games was never worth that. But those who doubted that a passably competent nation with unlimited cash could deliver two weeks of sport were wrong. The Games seems enjoyable and remarkably scandal-free.

More worrying is the impact on political discourse. Apparently any gesture of national prestige, glory and self-congratulation, once declared by government to be "worth every penny", is beyond rational debate. To quarrel with any feature of the games is to be a whingeing, unpatriotic naysayer. Normally hard-headed politicians (and journalists) have gone soft in the head – flat-earthers, creationists, climate-change deniers.

In 2005 Tessa Jowell was gushing that Athens had been rendered "a changed place: cleaner, brighter … vibrant and modern", when it was already plunging off the cliff. In his final bid for London 2012 in Singapore, Ken Livingstone dubbed it the "regeneration games". Locog's Lord Coe talked of the "Olympics profit". David Cameron burbles on about "making £13bn".

This is nothing to do with sport, nor with hosting the Games. It has to do with the manner of the hosting. There is a copious literature on the impact of big-budget sports events on host cities and how to avoid pitfalls. Studies from the International Association of Sports Economists (IASE) are relentlessly cautionary. Postmortems on Atlanta, Barcelona, Sydney, Athens and Beijing all tell of hotel slumps, unpaid debts, empty parks and subsequent disillusion.

A study of Sydney by Australia's Monash University found there was no tangible benefit "or economic boost" from the Games. An IASE report on Atlanta called Bidding for the Games: Fool's Gold? found that "diverting scarce resources from more productive uses translates into slower rates of economic growth". Civic leaders talk desperately of "legacy" but no survey can find any. Barcelona saw hotel occupancy fall from 80% to 50% in the year after the Games. The city's subsequent prosperity is now attributed to cheap flights and the Spanish boom. Beijing has seen no games-related uplift.

On London, an exhaustive 2006 report for the European Tour Operators Association pointed out that sport is a "notoriously narrowly focused" form of travel, with no spillover into wider tourism. "During the Olympics, a destination effectively closes for normal business," it warned. Mark Perryman's spirited survey, Why the Olympics Aren't Good for Us and How They Can Be, charts the same tale. More ironic is Mitchell Moss's How New York City Won the Olympics. It points to how, by losing the 2012 bid, resources allocated to the Games were diverted to the Lower West Side and other, now booming, locations.

There is no shred of evidence for claims still being made by the government and others of an Olympics profit, fast weakening to a "promotional legacy". Nor is there evidence of ministers recovering their brains. Today the culture secretary, Jeremy Hunt, described talk of ghost London as "absolute nonsense". The city was booming, he said, and "quids in". The sports minister, Hugh Robertson, attacked ailing businesses, saying: "This is hardly a surprise … there has been ample time to plan for [the Olympics]."

Their problem is they did. For years Robertson's department told everyone to prepare for a boom. Hotels raised prices and took on extra staff. Bus and tube drivers were paid bonuses to cope with the crush. Central London was told to expect an invasion and that residents should stay at home. This was the tone of every statement from the mayor, Boris Johnson, and his transport boss, Peter Hendy. Either these men were lying or their apparatchiks dared not tell them the truth.

I can find no warning in recent years from any official body that August 2012 would be anything but a cash-rich bonanza. Last week Johnson was still hyperventilating like Big Brother over tube loudspeakers that passengers should expect "a million extra visitors a day". He must have known this was rubbish. Reports were pouring in from London business associations of trade at hotel, restaurant, theatre and other tourist venues plummeting by an average of 30%. With August always down, they had been told to greet a "games uplift". They must have a strong case for a class action against the mayor, who has been milking the games for all the politics he can.

Clearly the authorities massively misjudged, but it was entirely because they refused to believe the evidence of past games. They were glory-blinded. Had the government said from the start that London was a rich city staging the Olympics as a costly but generous gesture to the world, there could be no further argument. Ministers said no such thing. From Cameron down, they claimed the games would make money, now and, if not now, then some time in the future. This was plain dishonest. Everyone knows there is no Olympic legacy, but, as with Santa Claus, we dare not tell the children.

London will not recover the cost of the Olympics and may as well forget it. Having spent the money we should at least lie back and enjoy it. But we should stop pretending. The real victims of London's mind-numbing mendacity will be the poor and hapless citizens of Rio in 2016. They really cannot afford it.

rank_251.title: We need collaboration to realise Olympic legacy
rank_251.text:
London 2012 gives us a unique opportunity to address the deep-seated inequalities that currently prevent children and young people in the six Olympic host boroughs from achieving their potential.

Despite progress in some areas such as antenatal care, the health and life chances of children in these boroughs deteriorates significantly between early and teen years.

One of the most important aspects of the games is to ensure that once the closing ceremony ends, the Olympic legacy really begins. It is vital, therefore, that any initiatives are evaluated effectively and grounded in evidence.

New analysis from the London Health Observatory (LHO), provides a baseline picture for Olympic legacy initiatives, and demonstrates an overriding need for a convergence between all the agencies involved in making change happen for these children and young people.

Two main conclusions can be drawn from the Child's play? report. The first is the clear benefit of antenatal investment to give mothers and babies the best possible start in life.

It is particularly encouraging that the London borough of Tower Hamlets is achieving notable successes in some of its health outcomes. The borough's low rates of smoking in pregnancy, high rates of breastfeeding initiation and immunisation for measles, mumps and rubella (that are heading towards 100%) indicate that it has acquired valuable expertise in commissioning maternity services; best practice that must be worth sharing between Olympic co-hosts.

The second conclusion is illustrated by our '400m health hurdles', which shows that early gains made in the antenatal period are not being sustained and as children get older, their health experiences become increasingly mixed. In four of the six boroughs, for example, six to 12-year-olds are less physically active than other counterparts in London, while a higher proportion of 13 to 18-year-olds in Tower Hamlets and Waltham Forest smoke compared to the London average.

Preventing teenagers from lagging behind requires significant investment in the early years – as heralded by the Marmot Review in 2010 .

In addition to presenting the current picture of health in the Olympic boroughs, Child's play? includes a health forecast, showing that several positive gains have been made over the last few years. However, this forecast also shows that trends over time have been difficult to interpret.

The true impact of London 2012 for those starting life in the Olympic boroughs can only be measured through regular monitoring of health indicators in conjunction with effective, long-term and systematic evaluation.

The LHO has called on all partners involved in delivering the health legacy to collaborate in committing resources to evaluate the impact of change programmes.

The last challenge highlighted by the report will be delivering the legacy in a new commissioning landscape. It is clear that progress can only be made collaboratively since no single body can have all the answers. Local authorities have to take the opportunity of reconfigured public health services to learn from each other. Alongside this, the Clinical Commissioning Groups (CCGs) need to commission co-ordinated population-based health services that work in tandem with both local government and the Greater London Authority.

If the 400m health hurdles were to be redrawn for the Olympic Games of 2020, it would be encouraging to find most hurdles safely cleared, a sunny health forecast and a coherent, collaborative commissioning process for the 2012 Olympic boroughs.

Dr Bobbie Jacobson is director of the London Health Observatory

rank_256.title: Olympic legacy: school sports provision patchy across UK, admits Jeremy Hunt
rank_256.text:
More money need at primary level, says minister after BOA chair calls for reform of school sports policy to increase participation

School sports provision is patchy in some places at the moment, the culture secretary, Jeremy Hunt, has admitted.

To continue the British successes of the London Olympics, it is important to ensure best practice is followed around the country, and to have more investment at primary school level, he said.

His comments follow Lord Moynihan's call for a major increase in government funding to build on the success of Team GB at the 2012 Games.

The British Olympic Association chairman accused the current and previous governments of "treading water" in terms of increasing participation.

Moynihan, a former sports minister under Margaret Thatcher, claimed school sport policy is "bureaucratic" and needs more money to fund a major expansion.

He said: "There is a need for radical reform and I am calling for more money. There needs to be a total commitment to ensuring a sports participation legacy that has to focus on schools and clubs.

"For seven years successive governments have been treading water.

"We have tens of thousands of kids watching great moments which will live with them for ever. The government should step up to the mark."

Hunt told BBC Breakfast: "I think at the moment school sport provision is patchy in some places, and we need to do what we can to make sure that the very best examples are spread throughout the whole country, and this is absolutely going to be a focus over the next few months and one of the things that we really want to take away from these Games."

He agreed that investment at primary school level was important, saying: "Primary school is where it all starts, and catching people young is incredibly important."

However, it was important to keep a sense of perspective, he said.

"When you were showing the medals table just then, we're third in the world. Actually the funding of sport has been one of the great successes. John Major set up the lottery in the early 1990s, and in the 96 Atlanta Games we won just one gold medal, we've already won 16 in these Games, and we are only halfway through.

"Other countries are now looking at the UK, and looking at our sport funding model, and seeing what they can learn."

Moynihan said children should be given the chance to try minority Olympic sports such as handball, and primary schools help to provide more sporting opportunities. Sport England's focus is on improving participation in the 14-24 age group.

London 2012 chairman, Lord Coe, who sat next to David Cameron in the Olympic stadium on Saturday night, said: "He [the prime minister] was very seized by the need to build on everything he was seeing in that stadium, whether it was the extraordinary performances of our teams, the ongoing challenges of getting more young people into sport, and also the extraordinary potential for the economic legacy.

"He is very seized by the need to leverage legacy from every nook and cranny of that project. There is a limited window of opportunity."

Labour's former sports minister Richard Caborn accused Moynihan of rewriting history.

"We did invest very heavily in sport under the Blair administration," said Caborn. "The success now in the Olympics is a result of the investment we put into UK sports.

"Moynihan shouldn't be rewriting history, he should be reflecting on what we did over the last decade to get us to where we are now. He is not acknowledging the work that was put in over the last decade.

"We put money into school sports and we invested money in elite sport and UK Sport. That has got us where we are."

Sir Menzies Campbell, former Liberal Democrat Leader and one-time holder of the UK 100m record, said: "I fully support Colin Moynihan's call for greater investment in school sport.

"For far too long in this country we have turned against competitive sport in schools but there is no doubt in my mind that if we are to sustain the wonderful legacy from these Olympic Games we must accept that competition is the very lifeblood of sporting achievement."

rank_103.title: London 2012: who is claiming credit for the Olympic Games?
rank_103.text:
As the medals pile up, the debate begins about who should take credit and what the Olympics mean for modern Britain

Who is claiming the Games?

1. Everybody

The Olympic opening ceremony. Photograph: Jewel Samad/AFP/Getty Images

This is for everybody, said Danny Boyle. And certainly, as success has built upon success at the Olympics, people have been quick to take him at his word. But after the cheering comes the search for deeper meaning.

2. Multiracial society

Greg Rutherford, Jessica Ennis and Mo Farah. Photograph: Martin Rickett/PA

To the Sun, the success of Team GB has been a triumph for the multiracial society. "Marvellous modern Britain unleashed upon the world," the paper said, reflecting on golds for Jess Ennis, Greg Rutherford and Mo Farah. "This is what Britain looks like today. Three Britons from wildly different backgrounds that gave this generation its 1966 moment."

A marvellous achievement for the melting pot, said Evan Davis on the Today programme. "A really fantastic advert for multicultural, multi-ethnic Britain."

3. Conservative values

Samantha and David Cameron. Photograph: Luke Macgregor/Reuters

But is that right? Not at all, says MEP Daniel Hannan, writing in Tuesday's Daily Mail. Under the headline "The BBC's wrong. The Olympics are a victory for conservative values", he writes: "It's a typical BBC tactic to rattle off 'multicultural-multi-ethnic' as though it were a single word, a single concept. In fact, the Olympic Games celebrate the precise opposite of multiculturalism." They are, he says, a victory for the armed forces, family values – as opposed to the meddling of "government agencies", for competition in schools and the unity of the United Kingdom.

The paper's leader column, fearful that liberals may be gaining an advantage from all that Olympic gold, weighs in. "They are a victory for British pride and patriotism, supportive families, shared loyalties and common values – whatever our ethnic backgrounds," says the voice of the Mail. "The Games are conservative values in action."

4. Private schools

Helen Glover, one of two British gold medallists who went to Millfield private school in Somerset. Photograph: Joe Toth/BPI/Corbis

The sport of claiming the Games extends to education. It shows the value of how sport is taught in private schools and highlights deficiencies in the state sector, said Brendan O'Neill, the editor of the website Spiked, writing in the Telegraph.

5. Regionalism

Yorkshire, which would be 11th in the medal table if it were a country, according to one local radio reporter. Photograph: Alamy

The Games have even been a boon for regionalism. According to the Yorkshire Radio reporter Jonathan Buchan: "If #Yorkshire was a country it would currently be 11th in the medal table above the likes of Japan, South Africa and Australia!" That view gained traction in the county and beyond. Buchan's observation was retweeted 3,000 times. "There must be something in the water, that and the Yorkshire pride," concluded Mick Hill, Jessica Ennis's javelin coach.

And if the Games continue on their current pleasing trajectory, there will be more of this. Everyone will take from London 2012 exactly what they wish. And what we learn at the end of it all is that success indeed has many fathers.

rank_197.title: Best bits: The Olympic legacy for the voluntary sector
rank_197.text:
Samantha Sparrow – knowledge and innovation manager at vInspired

The Olympics will inspire a new generation of volunteers: They will also engage local communities outside of London. It is important that we encourage this sense of community and inspire young people to continue volunteering. I know many first time volunteers involved in the Olympics and we need to capitalise on their enthusiasm and experience.

We need to create and develop opportunities that are not just sporting related: We must develop cultural and community-based opportunities. I believe that as a sector we have to get organised, as well as reach out and develop ways that people can get involved using all the tools at our disposal. We must be creative, positive and enthusiastic about using the Olympics as a way of increasing volunteering like never before.

The Olympic volunteering programme has taught us the importance of brand: I am increasingly interested in the idea of "brand" when it comes to volunteers. The sense of pride and engagement people feel when they are part of a movement is a great concept that we should think about when designing roles and developing programmes.

Susanne Rauprich – Chief Executive of National Council for Voluntary Youth Services (NCVYO)

I was amazed by the number of young people who were recognised for their contribution: Carrying the torch was a fantastic opportunity for young people, who are often viewed negatively, to be featured in their local communities. We need more moments like this for as many people as possible - that would help to build communities and bring people together.

I was impressed by the way in which the Olympics have influenced communities outside of London: I have watched with interest the range of events going on in all parts of the UK, specifically through the Cultural Olympiad. The Games Makers come from all over the UK and beyond – people travelled from Scotland and other countries, and there are volunteering roles at all the Olympic venues. My hope would be that the Games Makers will carry their experience back to their local communities and make things happen there.

One way of ensuring there is a lasting legacy is to make positive stories from the Olympics available to a larger audience: We could collect stories on existing websites and portals and there are numerous facebook groups, Twitter lists and other social media platforms where Olympic volunteers can remain in contact with one another that have been set up by Games Makers. We should find ways of making use of these sites to advertise volunteering opportunities.

Mike Locke – Mike Locke – director of public affairs, Volunteering England

The scale of the volunteering effort for London 2012 is important for volunteering in society: It has demonstrated how much volunteers contribute and how well, and has raised the profile of volunteering in public discourse as well as in government and policy-making circles. I was at the technical rehersal for the opening ceremony and it was amazing to see hundreds of volunteers in the performance.

Some successes to learn from LOCOG: We need to continue to create volunteering opportunities that give people a buzz and a sense of contributing to something important. Volunteering should be fun and we need to create more

appropriate opportunities for future volunteers by appealing beyond the main audience. We must also moderate the excitement and provide good inductions and training.

We need to have an evaluation of the Olympic volunteering programme: It has been frustrating to not have a proper evaluation in place. There are some individual university researchers who are surveying volunteers and interviewing people, but there are no funds for a full evaluation of the Games Maker programme. Perhaps voluntary organisations should organise to assemble and report on this data.

Olly Benson – YouthNet

The Olympics volunteering programme has taught the sector the importance of getting it right: It has shown the need to contact people quickly and to keep them informed. We must find ways of making volunteers feel valued. The Games Maker programme also highlights the importance of recognising how people feel when things don't go right or when they are uninformed.

Secondly, the Games have taught charities the importance of creating a value attached to their volunteering: Someone who is a Samaritans volunteer, or an RNLI volunteer, or a Scout Leader has a certain value attached to their role that is not just recognised internally, but by the wider public. Organisations need to think about how they publicly put volunteers at the heart of their operations. LOCOG intentionally didn't talk about volunteers, but gave them a distinctive brand of Games Makers to reinforce the fact that they were the ones who enabled the Games to happen.

Thirdly the Games have taught that it is important to be open to public scrutiny: I think organisations need to be prepared to allow their volunteers to talk about the good and bad experiences they are having, and then to learn from the feedback. I have heard about organisations that have barred their volunteers from talking about their experiences on public forums. LOCOG have had a lot of scrutiny of their programme and one thing organisations can take away from the Olymnpic volunteering programme is to ask themselves, how would their volunteering fare under similar levels of scrutiny?

Joanna Shaw – Public Zone

Charities need to be ready to mobilise people who have been inspired to volunteer by the Olympics: Be at the top of Google search results and make it easy for people to volunteer for you. After the Olympics there will be thousands of people in the UK who have been inspired to volunteer and charities need to ensure they are coming up in search engines. Eg. When people google ' I want to volunteer with children/sport/schools' they should aim to be top of that list.

There is a big role digital and social media can play: Organisations need to use the positive stories of the Games to promote and engage their online communities. Learnings, evaluations, stories and lessons learnt could benefit the sector hugely so we should find ways to curate these online. It is going to be difficult for the impact of the Games to be felt outside of London and digital technology could be really helpful. Volunteering organisations and charities who have supporters outside of London can use the content, stories and case studies generated throughout the Games and proactively push this out to people online. There is a huge opportunity for charities to use online resources to find people and to offer them volunteering opportunites. Central to this is the creation of good, relevant, searchable content, whether that is using social media or a website.

Make people feel proud to volunteer: Giving volunteers an identity like 'Games Makers' gives them an extra incentive to get involved and to shout about their experiences. I think LOCOG have been very successful in shifting perceptions about volunteering, showing that volunteers have real jobs and are often senior, experienced professionals and not always casual workers. An example of this is medical volunteers. The strong brand and 'Games Maker' identity has empowered volunteers to feel no different than official Olympics employees. The more charities treat their volunteers as real staff, the more effective and engaged they are. Having an official email address that volunteers can use can make a huge difference in making volunteers feel more valued.

Kate Bowgett – Association of Volunteer Managers (AVM)

I am cynical about whether there will be a lasting positive impact for the voluntary sector: I am not sure whether the motivation to volunteer for something like this is the same as the motivation to volunteer at a homelessness day centre or to mentor children in care. I am also a little sad that there seem to be a lot of people out there who have had a rather negative experience of applying to be a Games Maker, and I do worry that the bad press around that will put people off offering time to other organisations.

Good Volunteer Managers know that how you respond to people's initial enquiries is vital: A poor response may not just put people off volunteering for you, it may prevent them from ever offering their time again. Knowing that they would have vastly more people wanting to volunteer then they could possibly take on, I think LOCOG should have put more thought and planning into dealing with that, and maybe passing them on to Volunteer Centres.

One negative experience can end up being shared with a lot of people: There has been a lot of negative comment about the Games Maker programme and that is an important reminder to all volunteer involving organisations that now people share experiences online, one negative experience can end up being shared with a lot of people and not spending the time to get volunteer management right could end up being a bit of a PR nightmare.

This content is brought to you by Guardian Professional. To join the voluntary sector network, click here.

rank_242.title: Stratford's Olympic legacy: 'It's been far better than I thought'
rank_242.text:
London 2012 has put the area on the map, but for Newham the Games goodwill is mixed with less positive experiences – and the borough's regeneration means a tough political challenge

On the big, wide screen in Stratford's Langthorne pub, a cyclist pelted for the finish line and a London cry went up: "Go on, my son!" Sir Chris Hoy obliged, landing yet another Team GB Olympic gold and pedalling himself still deeper into Games history.

"I won't be sorry when it's over," confided Barry Wilks, a 10-year Langthorne regular, looking on. "But it's been better than I thought – far better. There's been a great atmosphere in here."

Barry had feared the worst about Games time: "In a word, I thought it would be manic – transport would be absolute murder." But his walk from nearby Plaistow has been no problem at all, and neither has his bus journey back home. Music from the Olympic Park has sometimes reached him through his bedroom window, he said, but that hasn't stopped him and his fellow patrons rising to the East End occasion.

"We've enjoyed having the foreign visitors. We've been very friendly to them. We've done our bit."

A duty as well as a pleasure, then?

"Of course it is."

Visiting athletes have been among the clientele, Wilks said: "Russians; Americans, drinking the British beer." He looked forward to the park reopening for public use next year. "I'm retired now, and I enjoy walking. Good for children, too. I'm very pleased."

His one strong complaint is that the Paralympics won't be shown on the BBC, but Channel 4 where ad breaks will intrude. "I pay a licence fee. Are they saying the disabled athletes shouldn't be treated the same?"

The Langthorne is on Stratford Broadway, a town-centre street separated from Stratford's teeming public transport hub and vast, new Westfield mall by a block that houses an older retail space. The Stratford Centre contains its share of high-street household names, but has been dwarfed by the giant newcomer since it opened last September.

In its indoor market, which looks out on to the Westfield side, traders' stories of their Games fortunes vary according to what they sell. Jawad Khan, standing amid packed racks of casual clothes, says business has gone up by 40%-50% since the Olympics began.

"Visitors are coming in for souvenirs," he said, nodding towards T-shirts with union flag themes, prominently displayed. "We're working seven days a week, until eight at night."

Others, though, complain that too few Games spectators are crossing the street and that those who do aren't buying what they have. "Horrendous," is the word Les Barry uses to describe his delicatessen's turnover. "We're 40% down." His usual local customers are on holiday or just staying away, deterred by parking problems and crowds. Les Berry has been been resourceful, bagging up portable snacks – "the olives have been going quite well" – but as he talks the wall of fresh eggs stacked behind him begins to look unloved.

Berry is not alone in believing that the ticketed droves pouring off trains across the way are being herded straight through Westfield to the Olympic Park turnstiles beyond, even actively discouraged from exploring Stratford itself. "We've all been expecting to be busy, but it just hasn't happened."

Back on the Broadway, though, the gold rush of goodwill so evident in London at large had touched some Stratford residents too. Carmen Song, who made her home there after arriving from the Philippines 27 years ago, said the Games has caused no problems for her. She's found the influx of visitors exciting, putting Stratford on the map, and is hopeful that it signifies continuing improvement. "When I first moved here I thought the area was no good, but it has just got better and better. New buildings going up everywhere."

But not everyone is basking in the glow. Just off West Ham Lane, on a footpath bordering Stratford Park, a group of local artists taking their display down from the railings have Olympic scepticism to spare. "As a local resident it's meant nothing, really," said one of them, Angela Daley. "No inclusion. Not enough jobs for locals. I spent the start of the Games in the Dordogne."

She said that she and her fellow exhibitors want to celebrate the Olympics "in a more artistic way", but haven't had the support they'd like from Labour-run Newham council, even though its leader and the borough's mayor, Sir Robin Wales, was due to pay a visit. Angela was pleased to have sold three of her works, but the broad feeling seemed to be that Big Art has dominated the remaking of Stratford. Arrivals at the station are greeted by the Shoal, a high, handsome sculpture of titanium "leaves" 250 metres wide. Anish Kapoor's ArcelorMittal Orbit tower looms wonkily from inside the Olympic Park.

Angela's sense of the small and local being crushed by regeneration's big wheels also informed her view of the longer-term economic benefits it's claimed the Games will bring. "I don't think it will make a lot of difference. The only thing that's happened is new retail jobs in Westfield. That's better than nothing, but where's the inspiration in it?" Her summing up? "I suppose we're all a bit disappointed in Newham."

The council would beg to differ. As in other host boroughs, it's easy to find residents who feel excluded by the Games – inconvenienced by its presence, while being unable as yet to go inside the Olympic Park. Yet on the other side of the Stratford Park railings, Wales has laid on a big screen, beaming the sporting action to all-comers for free. There are food stalls and entertainments too, although on a cloudy, drizzly Tuesday night the security staff who searched my bag as I entered almost outnumbered the punters within.

One of them, Nazmin Lalaounis, sharing a blanket on damp grass with her mum and a German friend from Forest Gate, described with animation her experience of the local mood. "Everyone I know is loving it," she says. "A few are moaning about too many people but that's all. There's a holiday atmosphere. My mum likes all the bunting. She wants it to stay."

There's a bit of pride as well. Nazmin, an office administrator, grew up in Dagenham, part of the very different borough to Newham's east. She describes having "a bit of a culture shock" when she moved to Stratford, with its huge ethnic and social diversity. But she soon took to defending it.

"People I work with used to joke that Newham was a place you just passed through. I would say, 'I live there, so go away!' But now Stratford at least is becoming a place to visit."

She recalled Jamie Oliver noting that Newham is rich in fried chicken takeaways, "but now, with Westfield, there's all sorts of restaurants and delis. It's given people an entry to a different world." There's been a wider Olympics effect, she said, going right back to when the Games bid was won in 2005. "It's made a difference to who is living in my street. A lot of people have moved out. I think it's the cost of living, especially for the ones who are sending money home to other countries. There's a lot more private renting. Some of the landlords seemed to take better care of their properties when the Olympics were getting near."

Nazmin is conscious too, though, of the drawbacks of such change, praising small-scale neighbourhood efforts to bind the established community together. Newham markets itself is a place where people "choose to work, live and stay". Wales wants to slow the borough's population "churn" and build "resilience" instead. As ever, though, regeneration can prompt an exodus driven by rising house prices and rents as new people with more money move in. On the Broadway, a street food trader who said he lived close by was bluntly resigned to the harshest parts of this effect. "The investment will be for people with money, and the poor will have to shift out. That's always the story. That's the regime."

Research by east London academics does not contradict this view. Monitoring housing scheme planning agreements along Stratford High Street since 2009, Dr Penny Bernstock and Professor Gavin Poynter report a "dramatic departure from previous commitments to mixed communities and on-site affordable housing".

Newham, like all the east London host boroughs, is pledged to achieve social and economic "convergence" with the richer, healthier west of the capital. But as Bernstock and Poynter wrote for the Guardian: "The danger is that this will be achieved by simply changing the population mix rather than transforming the lives of existing east London communities."

Avoiding that danger is the post-Olympic political challenge. Meeting it won't be easy. For now, though, there is excitement as well as cynicism in Stratford, an air of opportunity co-existing with the disappointments and doubts. Outside St John's church, a preacher spoke of his conversion from football delinquency and teenage girls performed a dance tribute to visitors from Brazil. Meanwhile, as dusk fell, shutters came down in the Stratford Centre and boy skateboarders replaced departing shoppers on one of its quieter avenues. Will their young Stratford lives be transformed?

rank_63.title: London 2012 legacy: Coe warns that children likely to be less fit than parents
rank_63.text:
The chairman of the London 2012 organising committee, Lord Coe, has warned that the current generation of parents are likely to be the first to be fitter than their children.

In a plea to politicians to capitalise on the success of the London 2012 Olympics, he implored them to recognise the complexity of the issues surrounding school and grassroots sport.

London's organisers won the Games promising they would inspire the nation's youth to play more sport. Coe said he was convinced that they had lived up to it but the "complex" debate over school sport should not be about political point scoring or become sidetracked by a debate over the relative merits of competitive sport and exercise.

"That cross-party debate I hope is a grown-up debate. The one thing that politicians of any hue now recognise is there is an appetite for that," said Coe, a former Conservative MP.

"People have voted with their feet in millions to support British sport. There are sports out there that have never been so popular. There is an appetite."

The shadow Olympics minister, Tessa Jowell, has called for a cross-party consensus on the best way to capitalise on the Olympic legacy.

"We mustn't confuse high quality physical education within schools, and competitive sport. They are, in essence, two different things," she said. "Done properly, they take you to the same virtuous outcome. Everybody recognises that giving young people a competitive outlet through sport is a very good thing."

Coe said he was wary of getting embroiled in a party political debate, but appealed for a particular focus on sport in primary schools. Specialist support for primary schools is set to be scrapped during the next academic year.

"It is my instinct that if you haven't got that pattern and love of sport and that pattern of exercise by year 10 or 11, it is going to be quite hard to introduce that to 14- to 15-year-olds with the cluttered landscape that you are then competing against," he said.

Coe called for a mature discussion that could lead to a long-term plan. "It is really important that we promote competitive support in schools," he said. "It is [also] very important that we recognise that has to be underpinned by good quality physical education and by getting people into patterns of exercise. We have to recognise that we are probably going to be the first generation of parents that are marginally fitter than our kids."

He insisted the inspirational effect of the Games on young people was real and there was a "limited window of opportunity" to capitalise.

"We have really inspired a lot of young people. When I go round the park, I see a lot of young people; in the venues, I see young people; in the streets, I see young people. There are a lot of young people in our venues," he said.

rank_85.title: Olympic legacy? We've still got a riot legacy to deal with | Michael White
rank_85.text:
Promises of outreach and investment, better facilities and job prospects have been patchily met and sometimes not at all

I think I'm right in saying there was more media coverage this week of the sentencing of the "Notting Hill mob", which rampaged through a fashionable London restaurant and shops during the August 2011 riots, than there was of the anniversary of the riots themselves. That's puzzling, isn't it?

All right, the first anniversary of the shooting of Mark Duggan in Tottenham on 4 August, and the rioting that spread through parts of London and other cities two nights later, coincided and contrasted with the surge of enthusiasm for the London Olympics, its growing success and the parallel achievements of Team GB.

Both took many people by surprise, not just those in authority, but ordinary citizens – horrified last summer, thrilled this one. Even the abysmal weather since early April has relented enough to retain only a bit-part in the collective Olympic memory, which (we hope) will sustain a warm glow through hard times. Wonderful!

But surely none of that can explain the extent to which the riots were blanked in many places you'd expect them not to be.

The Guardian carried an extensive series of reports based on LSE-conducted interviews with rioters – and took a lot of stick when they blamed the police. Likewise the Observer, the Mail (lots of convicted offenders have reoffended!) and the Sunday Telegraph – which reported that, one year on, a lot of victims are still waiting for compensation from an inefficient and careless bureaucracy – carried reports.

There's been a lot of talk about the Olympic legacy, but we have a riot legacy to deal with. Perhaps there was a blockbuster on the TV that I missed or in one of the political magazines I no longer monitor as I should. Overall I think we've chosen to look the other way.

There is a positive case to be made for doing so. In one bit of film I found – an NBC News report contrasting London's two Augusts – the Reeves family, who lost their five-generation furniture store in Croydon to an arsonist (since jailed), chose to stress the help they had received from the community and the efforts they are making to pay it back.

Their surviving store is plastered with upbeat notes this week and Maurice Reeves, 81, told the TV crew how good the feeling had been when the Olympic torch passed through the south London suburb. Corny, I know, but corny is often good. Someone called it "reverse rioting".

When I contacted a political chum in north London he said basically the same thing. Tottenham was cleaned up within days – only the stench of smoke and boarded-up buildings remained – but reputational damage was still hurting it and its retail businesses, he said. Perhaps the Olympics were a helpful distraction. Even cranky David Starkey wrote of "blessed amnesia".

Another reason for forgetfulness is that the government decided not to follow the instant inquiry route of the 1981 Brixton riots, after which a very weighty judge, Lord Scarman, delivered the scathing Scarman report. It highlighted "complex political, social and economic factors", not least heavy-handed use of police stop and search powers, and urged Margaret Thatcher's ministers to act to improve conditions and confidence in the police.

These were the days when Willie Whitelaw, an old-school liberal Tory, was home secretary and some steps were taken to reform the Met and police procedures. A new stress on community relations (rather than race relations) emerged from the rubble.

But this quote from Scarman could apply to an analysis today: "Without close parental support, with no job to go to, and with few recreational facilities available the young black person makes his life the streets and the seedy, commercially run clubs of Brixton. There he meets criminals, who appear to have no difficulty obtaining the benefits of a materialist society."

A lot of that sounds ominously familiar, doesn't it? Sharon Grant, widow of Bernie Grant, the Tottenham MP, told the BBC that stop and search rates in her area have halved, but that a lot of promises remain unfulfilled. The communications mechanism between police and locals, which broke down so disastrously between Duggan's death and the start of the riots, is still not repaired or improved, she said. Stafford Scott says similar things.

Indeed not. Duggan's family have still not been told exactly how he came to be shot by a police officer while being tailed as part of an anti-gun-crime operation. That's pretty shocking and gives some justification to claims routinely made – often rather too casually – that it could all happen again, only worse.

Acpo, the chief police officers' organisation, says it doesn't have "a standing army" to deal with disorder on this scale, as some countries, including France, have. The CRS riot police, hanging menacingly around in lorries at sensitive junctions, have been a sight in Paris for as long as I can remember. Were they there before the 1968 riots? I can't recall.

That doesn't mean that the police response – better in Manchester and Birmingham than in London – will be as feeble and poorly co-ordinated as it was in some riot boroughs of London in 2011. But we don't want to go down that road, do we? We want more constructive remedies than the iron fist Eric Pickles seems keen to wave. To flip an old joke, "a law-and-order Tory is a libertarian whose neighbourhood's been trashed".

Both oh-so-familiar camps in this debate have solid points to make. As with the Olympic legacy the riots legacy team made promises of outreach and investment, better facilities and job prospects, which have only been patchily met, sometimes not at all. These are hard times for the economy and public investment, though the Met's attempts to recruit more non-white officers ought to have been more successful than they look, hard times or not.

Richard Wilkinson and Kate Pickett, co-authors of that excellent book The Spirit Level, made another assault on what they call "the poison of inequality" in the Guardian last week. Lynsey Hanley, whose experience of life at the sharp end is more hands-on, makes another in today's edition. Even in Stratford, east London, the Games must look a million miles away to some residents.

But the "no excuses" camp – which includes a lot of unprivileged immigrant families of all backgrounds – have their case to make too. In its critique of the Guardian/LSE study, Reading the Riots, the Sunday Telegraph stated that stop and search rates and unemployment were worse in boroughs like Tower Hamlets and Brent, which did not riot last summer, and that shops, not police buildings, were the main target. The Footlocker looting jibe, a thieving spree by people who didn't expect to be caught, remains a potent one.

And do this summer's Olympic champions, drawn from heroically poor backgrounds like boxer Nicola Adams – her face across the Guardian's front page today – or the community effort in Flint which supported Jade Jones to her gold goal, as well as more upper crust winners, reinforce the message that poverty and disadvantage is no excuse for urban mayhem?

The usual suspects are squabbling over that one too. The answer is even more complicated and nuanced than a 100m final. Success in sport takes teamwork and money as well as individual commitment. But we can hardly blame those who look at Adams's grin and answer the question with an uncomplicated yes.

"Inspiration" is a sentiment more easily mouthed than achieved. When the Games are over who will have been inspired to do what?

rank_228.title: Olympic Games have shown world what Britain is made of, says Cameron
rank_228.text:
Prime minister vows that London 2012 will have positive effect on UK economy as he boasts of sporting and social legacy

David Cameron has declared that Britain has "shown the world what we are made of" and vowed that the success of the Olympics would leave a positive legacy for sport, volunteering and the British economy.

With Britain third in the medal table and the Paralympic Games still to come, Cameron used the midpoint of London 2012 to declare that "Britain delivered" and had shown itself to be "not a country whose time has been but whose time has come".

"We showed the world what we are made of, we reminded ourselves what we can do and we demonstrated that you should never ever count Team GB down and out. The lesson of these past weeks is that Britain can, and should, be ambitious.

"Frankly, we have got to dismiss the cynics who say we cannot do big things and prove them wrong. We in this country are going to make sure that these are not just Games that made history but the Games that helped to shape our future."

As the Games prepared to draw to a close on Sunday, a clearly cheered prime minister paid tribute to a "truly great country" where a boy born in Somalia, Mo Farah, could come to the UK, seize on the opportunities "and run his way into the nation's heart".

"Over the last couple of weeks we have looked in the mirror and we like what we have seen as a country," he said.
